Yes, it's rock solid. It'll likely survive any accident that could befall an exercise water bottle. It's holds alot of water. If you were stranded in a broken down jeep mid-way through the desert it would be a life-saver. For me though, suburban exerciser that I am, it's probably overkill. I exercise at home, and sip periodically while trying to follow the instructional DVD's on the TV. Occasionally I spill a bit because the mouth is so wide. It's too wide to grab and swig confidently in one hand without being fairly careful (and I have large hands even for someone over 6'). I've just ordered the CapCap to help with this (hopefully). If  I had to purchase again I'd get something smaller.

reviewText:
I bought these leggings at a discounted price in exchange for my honest review.

I am a substitute teacher and tend to end up in PE classes fairly often so I always need workout clothes.  I was very interested in these because they have a pocket for my phone which I need for notes, alarms and the stopwatch function.  However when these arrived they were far too thin to be school appropriate and you can see any other colors through the material.  The pocket was fine for my phone but as soon as I put them on and sat down I realized there was a hole in the crotch. I am also disappointed that there is very little structure to support the waist band other than the elasticity built into the fabric.  If this fabric stretches at all they will no longer stay up around my hips and may sag down which is pretty funky looking for leggings.  These are also not true to color.  Imagine the set in the picture left out in the sun for a few weeks and that's the color of "turquoise" you're getting.
summary: Thin, see-through material.  Not true to color.

reviewText: We've got a lot of children in my family so we always have a need for party gear. There's a birthday or a celebration for every month of the year. When I came across this electric balloon pump, this is exactly what I had in mind. There's no party without balloons so this got me excited about saving some money. I got the opportunity to get this machine at a discount in exchange for my honest review so I took the plunge and placed the order. It got here quickly and I tried it out right away being a little skeptical at how well this little machine would perform. It's a little loud, but it works great and delivers what it says it would. The two spouts make blowing balloons go twice as fast and it doesn't slow down when both are being used. It's very convenient and I KNOW this little machine will be put to use quite frequently so I'm hoping it keeps up with the demand. I'll do another update later if I find anything significant more to share about the machine. I really like this little thing tho. It's not too big so it makes for easy storage and so it doesn't take up much room when not in use. I do recommend this machine to everyone!
summary: Thank goodness for this! No more balloon-blowing woozies!

reviewText:
Great fit for my S&W Model 10 heavy barrel 4" (tried a round and square grip Model 10 for concealment purposes as well).  Thumb break goes over the end of hammer - not between the tang and the area where you put your thumb to cock it.  Just thought I would point that out even though I am perfectly fine with this method.  Easily released with a quick motion of the thumb while gripping the pistol.  Holster completely covers trigger which greatly reduces that chance of accidental discharge.  Fits nicely on the hip and with a un-tucked flannel shirt it was difficult to tell that I was carrying.  Feels almost unnoticeable on my hip and has a natural pull angle in my opinion.  Leather is quality material, finish is great, have no complaints.  Found myself really enjoying the holster.  I have a GP100 on order and will report back on fit when I have it in hand/holster.

Edit:  Nice fit for my GP-100 as well.  I did use the heat gun a for just a couple minutes on it to loosen it up a bit, but once I did that the fit was spot on.  Also tested it on a Colt Diamondback and S&W M19 and was good to go.
summary: Great Mobile Home for Your Six Shooter!

reviewText: this is a very big bag.  holds all my hunting clothes and items all in one bag.

I purchased this Spyderco Ladybug with the hopes of having a small, lightweight, and fully functional EDC (Every Day Carry) blade. Let me tell you...it does not disappoint and gave me exactly what I wanted!

Here are the specs:
#1) VG-10 blade steel

#2) Foliage Green FRN (Fiberglass Reinforced Nylon) handles with Spyderco's Volcano Grip which offers excellent slip resistance and feel

#3) Open length of: 4.375" inches or 111mm...Length closed is 2.438" inches or 62mm...Blade thickness is: 0.78" inches or 2mm...Blade length is: 1.938" or 49mm...Cutting edge is: 1.687" inches or 43mm...and the weight of this knife is a beautiful: .06 oz or 18g.....*Please Note* (These specs are taken directly from Spyderco's website itself, so they are accurate and true)

#4) Adjustable Torx pivot screw for blade retention adjustments

#5) Torx screw in handle for blade removal or cleaning

Pros:
 Arrived shaving sharp
VG-10 steel
Excellent Grip
Extremely lightweight (I'm carrying it in my pocket as I write this!)
Conceals very well
Smooth opening
plain edge knife

The Spyderhole IS usable despite it's small size

Wonderful color: It is a foliage green that is used in the U.S. Army's camo design and it actually does "shade shift" as Spyderco proclaims...against a gray background the knife seems to shift to a gray color, but against a darker green background it appears to turn a dark earthy foliage green.

Solid lockback lockup

Lanyard hole for paracord or any other lanyards!

Addjustable Torx screws for the blade retention and removal and or cleaning applications! HUGE PLUS!!! That is one of the big reasons I bought it! It's so little and still adjustable to your liking!

Cons:
I personally have none for the knife, however these are something's to keep in mind that others have mentioned:

#1) I have medium sized hands and if you have larger hands it may be difficult to get a good grip on to open it as it is small, but it's not impossible, it may just take some getting use to.

#2) The SpyderHole is small. It IS fully functional and can be open one-handed....however with bigger or gloved hands, it may take some getting use to as well.

#3) No pocket clip: This may be an issue to some, as you cannot clip it to you pants or a pocket, but I find it to be for the better. I like to slip this knife in the coin pocket in my jeans and it's not even noticeable, or when I go to the gym, it slips effortlessly into some loose shorts; It only has a lanyard hole as mentioned earlier. (***If you want a small knife such as this one WITH a pocket clip check out the Spyderco Dragonfly***)

#4) It is a lockback blade, so anybody living in a restricted area or under specific regulations such as the UK may have to check with local laws. However, Spyderco makes wonderful choices for UK or restricted knife law areas residents, such as the UK Penknife or any of the "Bug" series knives.

#4) Not made in the U.S.A.: This may bother some folks as some people like to buy "American only" made items. The Ladybug is made in Seki-City Japan and has fantastic quality control backing it...I mean hey, Spyderco's founder Sal Glesser carries one...it's got to be good!

#5) Some have mentioned that the name "LadyBug" is an embarrassing title to carry around with you....if it is a problem then Spyderco also makes the "ManBug", however I think this statement is just silly, it's a tool and hey if it works good, what does the name have to do with anything??? But it may rise some issues with some folks.

All in all I personally think Spyderco hit the nail on the head with this knife. It's small sure!, but don't let it deter you. You have to use it within it's limits. It is a small knife with big cutting power, but trying to split logs or cut thru mooring lines probably won't work to well.
It's an invaluable tool I carry on me everyday and I find at least 1 use for it everyday! Pair it with a small Streamlight Microstream, a Zippo, and a small multi tool, and you have a beautiful EDC setup!
 Whether it be cleaning your fingernails, to cutting a pesky loose string off your clothes, or to opening a package, this little Ladybug has you covered! I fully recommend picking one up if you need a lightweight, razor sharp, go anywhere knife that won't let you down and gives you more capabilities than one could think! Put it on a lanyard, toss it in a pocket, put it on a chain and wear it, or put it on a keyring, nobody should leave home without a LadyBug on their person!

I would also like to tell Amazon thank you for always getting my orders correct and on the time expected! I have been doing business with Amazon for years and I will certainly continue to do so. Excellent customer service, shipping, and prices! Keep up the good work!
~Christian~

This really does work, allowing me to keep both eyes open and able to see only 1 green dot with my eyes.

I shoot right-handed, and I'm left-eye dominant, and I can tell my left eye is picking up the green fiber front sight very easily and quickly.  I also noticed that if you think about it too hard and try to concentrate too much, you'll see a faint blurred 2nd sight.  But if you're going fast and relaxing your eyes and acquiring your targets by pointing your barrel where the target is at or flying by, then the green dot jumps out at you and you immediately see it and can hit the target with ease.

Just make sure you thoroughly clean your barrel before applying the adhesive strip to it.  And make sure you keep the 5-inch long sight straight it can look a little curved when you put it on the first couple of tries.

Personal fitness items are all the rage right now, and this type of product has been around for a while.  The perfect fitness ab carver sport is simply a better version of some of the old style of products that are meant to give you the same type of workout.

I am 35 and attend the gym 3 times a week (not in Olympic shape and I'm not going to win any marathons any time soon), but I liked this new version of the ab carver.

The ab carver comes in a box, and is really easy to assemble.  No instructions for assembly are really needed.  However, the ab carver does not come with instructions for how to properly use the wheel (although I think if you order this you already basically understand the premise).  The wheel is very sturdy, and easily supported me, I would imagine that someone of almost any size could use the wheel without a problem.

The exercise itself is somewhat strenuous.  I have always found myself sore after the first couple of days using the wheel, so it is not for someone that is only beginning a workout Regimen.  I'm sure you could strain yourself pretty easily with this workout tool.

As far as working out your abs this machine does exactly what it promises.  The issue with any tool like this is that it can hurt your shoulders, and your knees, but I'm not sure there is a way around that (with this type of exercise).  The handles can be a bit awkward, and the exercise itself takes some getting used to.  This certainly will not solve all your fitness problems, but it is a nice little wheel to have around for a workout.
summary: The perfect fitness ab carver sport is simply a better version ...

reviewText: I cautiously bought this believing the review where it was stated that maybe people do not know how to install this.  However, upon receiving it, this is probably one of the most simple pieces you could get.  That being said, maybe I recieved a defective version, because it did not fit into my G23 Gen4.  For one, it isn't even near flush with the bottom of the grip and here is why.  Looking inside the pieces where it can slide onto the rails inside the handle, there seems to be posts that are in the way of a tight fit.  I do not use backstraps so I double checked and put one on to see if that was the problem.  It still would not fit.  It actually sits about 1-2mm outside the handle on the bottom.  Normally I would not care, however because it doesn't seat properly, I cannot secure it because the holes are not even lined up for the screw.  I would have to glue it in to secure it.  Because it does not create a perfect seal, I hesitate to do that giving that I may have to clean up there someday.  Great product and idea, just does not work for my model.

This is a large watch...nearly as large as my Suunto but due to its articulated strap it fits on the wrist very well. This is my #1 water bottle - the "don't even think about touching it!" bottle - the bottle I give as gifts, and I was a major Sigg fan.

Why so awesome:
1) Has NEVER EVER leaked - even when I left it filled side-wise "open" in my car - can be tossed in the bottom of a 6th grader's bag and not spill over his math homework that is also inexplicably at the bottom of his bag
2) No funny after-taste (granted I have never left it prolonged in direct sun exposure or in a hot car)
3) Bite valve easy-to-use, I have no trouble using it even during extreme can-barely-get-a-word-out cardio
4) Fits perfectly in standard bike cage and carabiner clip gives great place to grab to pull it out for single-handed use but is also fairly light
4) Wide mouth means it is easy to clean and also easy to drink from
5) Replacement straws and bite valves easy to find (online)

Bottom line: If you are at all serious about drinking from a water bottle, GET IT NOW.
summary: Excellent from bike to school to work to gym

I really have enjoyed this pack so far, I bought it because I saw it was rated as the best buy backpack on outdoorgearlab, and after hours of online comparison shopping, I finally pulled the trigger. I was hesitant about the color, and only chose the green due to the cheaper cost ($60 less than the blue), but it actually looks pretty awesome in real life and I have no regrets as far as looks go.  I was unsure 60L would be enough space and was tempted to go bigger, but for a 2-3 backpacking trip like I did, it was just right.  I think it would have been fine for about a week trip actually.  I did have to buy a compression sack to fit my sleeping back in the bottom of the bag, but I'm sure that's standard for any internal frame bag.  The only thing that I would say could be better for a skinny guy like myself is the hip padding.  My brother in law has a very similar osprey bag with the same padding setup, and didn't have any soreness, but I am skinnier and was pretty bruised up on my hips after carrying around 35-40 lbs for 20 miles.  I have another osprey backpack (a very high end child carrier, can't remember the name-too lazy to look it up) and I had the same problem, and I really think its a skinny person problem that would happen with most any backpacking bag.  I think I will try to see if I can use moleskin and a large bandage on my hips for the next time I use it, or see if there is some way to retrofit additional padding as I was in a lot of pain for the last 5 or so miles of the hike.
summary: I really have enjoyed this pack so far

Extra long to reach the water on high gunnel boats.  Collapsible to save deck or cabin space.  Rugged enough for my 250 pound brother. I gave it four stars because I had tape up the end caps with white electrical tape on the gunnel hooks and on the stand offs...otherwise they tend to pop off with constant use. Bought these for a 50th Anniversary .357 Blackhawk.  Correct grip/revolver match.  The instructions were extremely basic but there was input from others online who had problems installing.  Got the gun in a vise, poked, prodded, stretched open, used a heat gun.. even removed the original grip roll pin.  Nothing, including a rubber mallet, worked to get it on that last bit.  I've given up and they're going back.  I may try the expensive Hogue wooden model now since I still want a full grip.

Maybe there are minor variations in grips and guns.  Maybe it's simply not close enough to a consumer install design though, honestly, I'm not completely helpless in a shop and had the right tools.  I'm giving it an extra star because for those that can get it to work, the grip, while quite ugly, works wonderfully.  If you're want a a full grip and getting the most out of your revolver as a shooter rather than a wall hanger, you won't be disappointed.  No more orphan little finger.. hand filling and grippy.  Really wish I could have gotten it installed.
summary: Liked the Grip Could Not Get Installed

reviewText: This mount has zero tolerance for lights or lasers.  I purchased it for my light and unfortunately, it doesn't fit.  The light fits other mounts, but this one is a solid tube machined out of aluminum with a tab cut for clamping the light in place.  There is no way to expand the housing to fit a light or laser even temporarily to get it in place.  If you have a Dremel tool, you can remove the screws and cut an expansion slot between the clamps, but obviously, there are risks with that and will clearly void any warranty or return option.

reviewText: Love it!

I've carried a Benchmade 940 for the last 7 or so years, and I wanted to see what all the attention for Spyderco was for. This is my first Spyderco knife, and I gotta say, the fit and finish is as close to flawless as I can possibly imagine. Great steel, light and rugged. I didn't think I'd like the opening hole, but it works just fine. Overall, great knife that I plan on getting some good use from.

I bought this rifle case in 46 inches for a friend as a thank you gift. He usually helps me out of jams whenever I need something welded, drilled and tapped or milled. I prefer to check the reviews of a product before I buy it. This rifle case does get good reviews on multiple sites. Before giving it to him, I just had to check it out for myself. Since this rifle case has a divider for two rifles, I was able to place a 20 inch AR 10 style rifle with a scope and bipod on one side of the divider and a 20 inch AR on the other side of the divider. As for the front magazine pouches, I was able to place the following magazines into the pouches comfortably. I was able to place 5-30 round Magpul PMags into each front magazine pouch. Next, I was able to place 4-20 round Magpul LR/SR PMags into each magazine pouch. Then I was able to insert 8-32 round Colt style 9mm AR magazines into each magazine pouch. I really liked this feature. If needed as a bugout rifle case, it would work out nicely.
Seems very well made, courteous company as well!

The last scope mount I had on my rifle would let the scope move backwards a little at a time.  This mount has maybe 5 times the contact surface on the gun and one more screw to secure it.  I have not had any movement of the scope with this mount.  I think it is the right design for the slot on top of most 22 rifles.  I would certainly recommend it to a friend.  I actually do not find anything about this product that I do not like.

reviewText:
Easy to assemble and to get up to speed...
Solid construction, comfortable ride.
Rowing experience is what you get out of it is what you put into it - feels great.

Documentation is the one and only problem (and easily solvable by Concept2):
Quick Start Guide: 26 glossy pages - only 2 usable by English reading user.  What-A-Waste!
Product Manual: 34 glossy pages - what is usable by English reader can be reduced to 1 page. What-A-Waste!
Also, the manuals refer you to their web site to get instructions.

If I am sitting at the machine, am I likely to page through instructions on a computer screen? I think not.
I went to their site and copied and pasted from the wonderful info there into a Word file, deleting any reference to PM3, PM4 and "logcard".
Then printed it out - 26 non glossy pages of useful information that my family and I can quickly access and keep rowing.

Solution for Concept2: Allow user to request the language they would like and then provide that manual.
Only print users' requests.
It doesn't have to be wasteful glossy paper either - doesn't matter.
OR send a Word file.
Come on! For a thousand bucks?

2 minor irritations:
How do you reset a false start - and start again?
How to you stop the monitor immediately - other than just stop rowing and walk away?
Concept2 - are you listening?
summary: Wonderful machine, but give me a manual I can use!

Note: This review is for the 8-person tent without the Air Pad and Air Pillow

At about 17 pounds, this is a much lighter tent to take with you when compared with similar 8-person tents from Coleman. Not only that, it is easy to store and for an 8-person tent, does not take a lot of space and comes with a nice storage bag.

The tent is easy to set up with the included instructions. Although instructions are easy to follow, it would be even more helpful if Amazon included a short video that demonstrated the steps to assemble and disassemble.

I have yet to use it on a camping trip because the season doesn't allow it but I have tested assembling and disassembling it. For an 8-person tent, this does seem to have enough space. However, if all 8 are more than 6 inches tall, the space may be too tight to sleep comfortably.

The tent fabric is 100% polyester with poles made of fiberglass. They are really high quality and I have no concerns about it for taking on a camping trip in rainy weather.

Overall, this is a very high quality, light-weight, and easy to assemble tent for your camping adventures.
summary: High quality, light-weight, and easy to assemble tent for your camping adventures

These thermal blankets are an absolute must for your survival pack.  Although they are designed to be used against your body while wearing very little clothing (maximum heating effect occurs when placed directly against your skin), they will help keep you warm while you are fully dressed.  They are also thin enough to cut into pieces to put against your skin under your clothes (chest, legs and arms).  As others have indicated, they do have a variety of uses.  If you must improvise, adapt and overcome to survive, it will be much easier with these in your arsenal!

It is better than the old Lee I have been using....which bothered my thumb and was difficult to use for Lapua brass seating.
It has a good body design that has heft, fits your hand better and some good leverage, even with the new Lapua brass.  However,
I have reservations about the durability of the little rails that come in and hold the cartridge while priming.  They slipped a couple of times, and when they do, the power you are putting on the lever to seat a primer is suddenly gone as the brass ejects from the holder...with pain to the hand exerting the force and quite often a pinched finger with a blood blister.  The only other thing I would say is the primer case, and plastic insert to change from Large to Small primers is Micky Mouse.  The tray is garbage, and I suspect it will break at sometime, and does not flip the primers as easily as others. One of the most infuriating thing about this tray is that when you get the primers flipped in the tray and then put the tray cover on...when it snaps on, many primers flip over the opposite way.  It is INFURIATING..  Like all of RCBS products, they are mickey mouse, flimsy and low quality.
summary: I seem to never learn...to just dump RCBS

The skin is made up of a durable material. I had used the "PARTYSAVING Portable Privacy Outdoor Pop-up Room Tent Camping Shower Toilet Beach Park" when I had driven across the country from California to Washington D.C. two months ago. It was a long 3,000 miles trip that provided me with the wonderful privilege to visit tons of national parks, and I must say that the Portable Privacy Outdoor Pop-up came in real handy.

First, the frames that provide the scaffolding retained its dexterity and tough strength over the prolonged consistent use. Additionally, the nylon-like fabric is sturdy enough not to rip against the frames' force. I think, maintaining the integrity of the product's structure is important, granted that the fabric provides the privacy for people in many situations.

I have also used the Outdoor Pop-up Tent as a shower room. I fill up large plastic bags with water and put two holes in them, adjust and secure it on the tent somehow, and take a shower :) The water pressure is not exactly a motel quality, but it does its job when you're out in the wild. Oops, I got sidetracked. The Outdoor Pop-up tent is sturdy enough to hold up the weight of the plastic bags  this is the point that I was trying to make.

reviewText: Great customer service and I'm very pleased with how well these lights work.  The rear light (red) you can actually detach and hook on your pants/armband etc. if you're a runner like I am; very useful.  Definitely recommended for any bikers out there. Overall a good product. I've had it for several months and used it many times. I prefer to buy American, and this is better than the imports I'm familiar with. It's a solid steel square tubing frame with steel bolts going through threaded plastic parts (metal would be better but I haven't had any problems), and the end caps for the tubes are plastic, which are holding up fine. One of the plastic threaded parts was missing on arrival, but CTK immediately sent me another one out at no charge. The carpet on the buttpad was a bit crooked and unevenly cut, which was poor quality control. The glue on the padding under the carpet is not great, so it worked itself loose after some use. I trimmed it and re-glued it, and no problems since. Same with the Y front carpet. There's no rear strap or backstop for recoil, but the upside to that is you can get a good shoulder purchase on your rifle, which I like. I just want something hold it still while I zero, and this works better for me and is more convenient than a front bipod and rear bag or plain sandbags. I would like to see a square flat front rest with a bag that adjusts to width made available as an option. The Y is versatile and accommodates all my rifles from traditional stocks to big quad rail assault rifles, and also works well as a pistol and revolver rest. Instructions consist of only a parts diagram, which I was able to decipher pretty easily. It's a good rest but I was expecting perfect fit/finish/quality from the reviews. I subtracted one star for the QC issues of the missing part and carpet cut/glue. Even though I have nit-picked over some suggestions for CTK, it is a very good rest for the price. It's better than anything in this price range and even competing products costing up to twice as much, which are all made in communist China. If you're like me and don't have a grand or more to spend on a really high end American rest, buy this one, it's the best you'll get for the money and is overall a solid American product.

I have to admit it was a several hour project getting them just right.  First, the metal fender supports with the holes to accept the SS rods seemed like they were made for a narrower fender - I pulled them apart a bit and re-aligned the tabs and they were fine.  The instructions say to place the plastic tips on the rods before inserting into the tabs - my rods were a half inch too long so I needed to disassemble everything and re-assemble without the plastic tips to get the fitting just right, I then marked the rods for cutting; took everything apart, cut the rods and reassembled everything.  Expect to have them on and off a few time before you nail the fit.

I'm knocking off one star because a good set of instruction would have saved me some time and aggravation, BUT I can honestly say they look so good on the bike I ordered a pair for my wife.

I took this pack on a month long trip around Europe and across a few states. The good news is that Southwest, WOW, Iceland Air, Vueling, and Ryan Air all seemed to think this was a carry-on. It fit under my seat just fine, and was big enough to hold 20lbs of clothes and travel supplies. The bag did get a little beat up and I'm going to send it back to Osprey for repair, but I'm very happy with this bag.

If you are anticipating rain please consider waterproofing this bag or buying a cover as it isn't going to protect your electronics in a storm. I would not use this bag as a schoolbag/work bag as it simply isn't laid out for that but it would make a for a good medium range hiking pack.

I'll definitely be using this for travel in the future.
summary: I'll definitely be using this for travel in the future.

reviewText:
My favorite bottle until now was the nalgene wide-mouth canteen.  This fella was a present from my bro.  It is sturdy, and I have used it for about two months now without problem.  I haven't used it for hot drinks simply because I don't like drinking hot drinks. I imagine that this plastic vessel is sturdy enough to handle 160F, perhaps not boiling.  Since it is not insulated, ice doesn't last long.  I generally drink cool fountain water or melted iced tea.  My university has lots of water-filling stations, and my work (hospital) has silver-ion ice machines and water dispensers.

Many other people have said that their bottle broke.  I am terribly rough with my stuff, but the flippy handle and push-button mechanism has held up well.  I can fill it through the drinking spout(quite nice and wide) or through the cap opening when completely unscrewed.

The top has a cushion around the mouthhpiece, and the cap has a silicone o-ring that is easy to clean.  Love it!

These are my first ever pair of Oakleys.  I bought them primarily for running and cycling.  I had been wearing cheap supermarket sunglasses prior to these, and never had a pair last more than a month or two without breaking.  Fortunately, the Flak Jackets have performed flawlessly for me over a long Summer of pretty heavy abuse.  My number one requirement was that they needed to stay put on my face, without breaking due to snugness.  In that regard, the Flak Jackets have been perfect.  I have never once had an issue with them falling off or needing to be adjusted mid-run.  They are also showing no signs of stress or breakage whatsoever.  Additionally, the optics are night and day better compared to the cheapies I had been wearing before.  Everything is crystal clear, and water and sweat just kind of beads off the lenses.  These certainly aren't inexpensive, but they are easily worth the Amazon price I paid for them.  I would definitely buy them again.

As a side note, I had initially purchased the Half Jacket 2.0s, and they were way too snug for my wider face.  So if you have a wide face and can't decide, the Flak Jackets are probably a better bet over the Halfs.

I purchased this bike based on the reviews, and so far I am quite satisfied.  I enjoy spin classes but it is hard to get out.  I did not want an inexpensive bike, but did not want to go over the top either.  Also 'electronics" are important to me.  I like to have a heart rate monitor, speed, etc.

So far I am very impressed.  Ordering direct as I did the transaction went smoothly.  The shipping company was easy to work  with.  They do show up in a big tractor trailer, but will help get the bike to your garage.  But remember it is basically a street delivery.

The packing was excellent, there was not a scratch on the bike.

Assembly, if you read the instructions is about 30 minutes.  25 of the 30 minutes is reading the instructions.  It goes together that easily.

The bike is heavy and on an initial spin very stable, quiet and smooth.  The electronics are as advertised.

I will give this bike a good workout and hopefully get back and ad to this review.

Concerns:  The transmitter for speed could be a little vulnerable and looks delicate.

UPDATE:

I have been on this bike for about six weeks.  I really love it.  It is solid, stable, smooth and silent.  I use chrome cast on my laptop to transmit Spin VIdeo's to my widescreen TV.  There are some really good videos available.  I do videos that are 30-60 minutes long and really enjoy the workout.  This spin bike was a really good purchase.

Expensive but considering the quality it's not too bad.  I considered the cheaper stands but the bad reviews sent me back to the Park.

The build is rock solid - solid metal hardware and tough abs-like plastic parts.

The raise/lower clamp requires an allen key to adjust.  You can buy a knob from a hardware store to fix the annoyance.  It wouldn't have killed park to just include a knob.

The bicycle clamp is fine for typical aluminum frames but be wary on carbon fiber frames and seatposts.  There are of course precautions and work-arounds that can be taken.  I also believe there are alternative clamps that can be purchased.  I suppose Park believes that if we spend the money on carbon fiber we should shell out proportionately more for repair stands.

Overall, an excellent product for a less than attractive price.  I would shop around more next time knowing there aren't many alternatives.

My Sig Sauer SP2022 compact 9x19mm with attached Sig Sauer STL900WLL (2013 model with switch not button operation...Which I assume pushes the laser/light out one rail spot forward) fits perfectly into this nylon holster.

The bezel of the light is left open to the elements, which is a negative for me, however it does not protrude from the holster (Which I suppose is good enough considering the lack of options I searched for on-line). Otherwise, the fit is snug, however unholstering is easy enough.

The nylon is stiff and rigid which is good for maintaining the shape/configuration of the holster and for overall protection of your firearm.

I removed the leg straps as I really only wanted a holster to place my firearm in while at the range...Although I did maintain the drop-leg belt attachment (The option to holster my firearm, however keep it on my body is a requirement). My set up may not look as tactically sound as if I were to have the leg straps, nor as sleek if I were to remove the drop-leg belt attachment, but neither is what I am using this holster for. I primarily want protection and safe holstering of my firearm, and I want to be able to easily attach the holster to my belt yet also be able not have too much dangling from the holster when I return it to my range bag.

The durability of the holster is superb, the stitching is secure, the ability to adjust for size is convenient, the configuration options are unmatched, the value is there! Outside of spending the time ordering/waiting and money for a customized kydex holster, if you have a firearm with a light or laser/light combination, this is very well worth it!
summary: Perfect Fit For my Sig Sauer SP2022 with laser/light attachment

reviewText: Hard hitting, easy to cock and shoot.  The trigger is a bit long and rough but there are fixes out on the web.  I think the longer trigger pull adds a bot of safety for the novice shooter. There are several youtube videos on how to improve the trigger after the warranty runs out.  Some "fixes" shorten the trigger travel while others shorten the travel AND reduce the trigger pull.  I'm getting dime-sized, 5-shot groups at 25 feet, quarter-sized groups at 50 feet, and silver dollar sized groups at 75 feet using the "artillery hold" with the factory trigger after 50-round break-in.  I don't shoot beyond 75 feet.  I use Crosman Premier Domed pellets. This is a hard shooting air rifle that nearly penetrated 3/4 inch pine at 20 yards (it split the wood on the back side but did not exit .  Although the  scope has been maligned in some reviews, I've been quite happy with mine.  I especially like the adjustable focus on the eye relief.  You can also adjust the objective lens for clearer short range focus if you know what you're doing.  Just be aware that you will give up far distance (> 100 yards) focus if you focus the objective at 30 feet.
summary: Hard hitting rifle with tight groupings

I ordered my helmet last Sunday to arrive on Thursday. On Tuesday I crashed my Mobility Scooter going down an improperly installed handicap cut out at a curb. No helmet. Within minutes I was on the way to the ER, Code 2.

Cat Scan, X Rays, the works. I am on Coumadin and because I struck my head in the fall they were concerned I might have a cranial bleed. All tests were negative. Had nasty road rash on right arm and leg.. The Mobility Scooter was undamaged as my body took the fall.

I now wear my helmet if in the driveway of my New Mexico home.  As a retired First Responder  I should have known better. I also purchased fingerless gloves to complete my safety  package.

Strongly recommend helmets. My Scooter has a top speed of 5 MPH. If you fall just right and have no helmet you are in serious trouble. If you do not desire to test the limits of your health plan, buy a helmet.

Nice design, bitchin color, sure to attract the opposite sex, I am 71 years old. In closing, this helmet is a good buy. Give it as a Christmas present.
summary: How important is your head to you?

Another quality Monstrum Tactical product. I recently purchased 2 of the 150 Lumen Tactical lights with rail and those are perfect size for my Mossberg 590 Shockwave + 16" barrel ultra light AR-15 with collapsible stock. Ordered one of these Ultra Compacts and yes, this thing is tiny. Takes one battery where the 150 Tactical takes 2 batteries. Amazing thing is when compared to the 150 Tactical, this tiny ultra actually has a whiter spot beam and puts out a higher level of light than the 150 Tactical (which has a duller spot pattern. Must be the design diff in front lens area. Mounted the ultra on my Shockwave but it is a little to small, not as easy to reach as it's Big Brother the 150 Tactical. However, it is definitely brighter and a richer spot beam, which would go on the subject for home defense. What a dilemma I'm in!!! Both are amazing lights for the money!! Great material, just go slow and easy with the mounting screws. I am very careful with installs and the head on the screw which holds the ultra onto the mount stripped although I had the supplied allen wrench bottomed out. I think it was slightly smaller when made. Will call Monstrum and with their excellent customer service, I know they will ship me a replacement screw. This little light is so compact that I am purchasing a 2nd one to keep in my truck. Not sure about the battery life or if it will withstand a 12GA shot. It does state rifles and shotguns but common sense tells me for the price, most likely would crack the led bulb or ruin tailcap. Only improvement on this Ultra would be a larger tailcap button. A little small for my larger fingers but it still works. Bonus is the included pressure switch and cap if you are into those options. Very cool Ultra light.
summary: Awesome very smal shirt pocket white bright spot beam flashlight

Any Buck Mark owner that has one with a thicker bull barrel configuration be forewarned: this rail may not seat properly on your gun. This is the case with my Hunter, where the top of the barrel at the breech end stands slightly proud of the receiver it abuts. The rail mount's underside is not machined to fit such a barrel configuration, where it is shaped flat instead with a concave groove (like the factory Weaver rail that comes with the Hunter) at that end of the rail. Only barrels that have been machined with a flat top at the breech end will properly seat this rail.
summary: Works with some Buck Marks but not all

reviewText:
This BikeLight is a solid light, especially considering the cost and what it includes.  As listed in the description, you get the following:

1 Light + Mount
1 TailLight
2 18650 batteries (My favorite battery type)
4 CR2032 batteries (think watch batteries)
1 18650 charger + 18" charge cable (microUSB)
1 AAA insertion pack (Replacement for those who prefer AAA over 18650)

So the package that you're getting for the cost, is immensely impressive.  I'm giving it 4 stars for a couple of reasons, none of which qualify the light or package as sub-par, simply noting a few issues that other lights improve upon, though often at a price hike.

Also note: I used Orbtronic 3100mA 18650's over the batteries provided by Sunspeed.  They are the best 18650's I've found and come with protected circuits, which are highly recommended on batteries that store as much power as 18650's do.  Anyway, on to the nit-picking

Good Points:
Focused beam - the main light can be rotated at the head to focus the light down to a 3' circle at 40' away -- and then broadened out to a less bright, but wider beam for road riding.
Rechargeable batteries - Including 18650 batteries with the set is pretty awesome
3 Settings - A high beam, low beam, and strobe function
Tail Light - Bright and visible, can also be set to solid or strobe function
Easy Mounting - Mounts to your bike via a C clamp that closes to form a full O.  The included tightening screw has a large enough surface and grooves that make it easy to finger tighten

Slight Issues:
Brightness - the beam from this light has a slight blue haze to it, which isn't bad, but it detracts from the total brightness.  In comparison tests, it was far less luminescent than it's competitors (See pictures).
Unknown Battery Maker - As mentioned earlier, 18650's have the potential to start major fires if they are not monitored during charging.  Even with smart chargers, batteries that do not have internal protection circuits have a small potential to overheat and start a fire.  While the batteries are nice, if you can't charge them outside, it's recommended to invest in some reputable batteries or transition to the less powerful AAA variant.

But all in all, this is a great bike set.  I have it installed on a Schwinn hybrid bike I bought 4 or 5 years ago and I thoroughly appreciate the usefulness it provides at night.

Guess what - I got this light in exchange for a review, I like to think I'm honest and fair.  If you don't agree, please let me know

Test Lights Listed Below:
SunSpeed Light
TaoTronics ThorLite (quoted lumen rating - 500)
CygoLite Expilion (quoted lumen rating - 850)
Serfas TSL-S500 (quoted lumen rating - 500)
Boruit RJ-5000 (quoted lumen rating - 5000 LOL)
summary: Don't become roadkill - Get a bike light

reviewText: Great product!

I received my Kurt Kinetic trainer last week and am very pleased. It wasn't the cheapest one, but I'm glad that I bought it. I had it set up and my Trek Verve 2 installed in 30 minutes. I didn't need to change out the axle, because my stock one fit perfectly into the coned cups. A little background here. The last time I rode was in 1964, so I'm out of the biking loop. I made a lot of progress in a couple of months, and don't want to lose my gains over the Ohio winter. Based on many reviews here, I got the Kurt. It was easy to set up, and is very sturdy, and does not rock around when pedaling. Many people had noise issues with their tires, but mine are surprisingly quiet. I barely have to turn up the volume while watching a movie. What I hear is a whirling noise and it is not annoying at all me. I bought the front wheel riser block to keep the bike level. I did order a tire in anticipation of noise, but it will not be used until the stock tire dies. This tire can be used for normal road use too, so it won't go to waste. My tire size is 700 x 35. Schwalbe Kojak Folding Bead Tire Also, others have complained of rubber coming off their tires. I've got an hour and a half on mine and there is no rubber on the spool or clean basement floor. My spool is exactly at 90 degrees to the wheel. This would be something to check for those losing rubber. Perhaps something is skewed. I'll repost if I have any issues in the future. Now I need a wireless computer that is strong enough to send a signal to the handle bars. [edit] I've had this unit for about a month, and do 30 minute sessions, 4 times a week. There is positively no tire shredding or oil leaking, ... or any drama at all. It just plain works, and I would buy the same model again if the house burned down. As an aside: I have 3 # dumbbells that I use while pedaling to keep my arms and shoulders in good condition. It just does not make sense to only use the lower half of your body. You can buy them anywhere, but here is a link to see what I'm talking about. SPRI Deluxe Vinyl Dumbbells (Set of 2) Cheers, Packrat1947

Received today, as expected.

Upon inspection, found it to be a solid, no-nonsense, extremely sharp tool, which I probably would enjoy using for a long time.

Unfortunately, I also found a small rust spot which extends to both sides of the blade.

I called Amazon for a replacement, which I was assured would arrive in two days.

I'll update.

UPDATE 10/13/2013:
Replacement arrived in two days, as promised by the great folks at Amazon. Way to go, Amazon!

I've upgraded the item's star rating to a five from a four.

The kukri is great overall - just be aware that it is high carbon steel, and the same qualities that make it easy to sharpen and to keep it's edge, happen to make it susceptible to rust. SO - between uses, keep it oiled, after use, wipe it down and oil it (out in the field I've used oil from my truck's dipstick - I now carry a can of 3 in 1 oil in the truck). After I get the kukri home, I put some kerosene on a ScotchBrite pad and scrub the kukri, removing all vegetative and zombie crud. Then, if needed, I'll give it a "touch up" with a fine file, oil it, and put it back in it's sheath.
The knife (machete) has good balance in the hand, the metal is heavy and strong enough to handle it's intended task,and the Kraton handle is superb.

About the sheath - the sheath could be better quality, there's no doubt. What I found was that the leather is very stiff, and dry. The two little closure straps with snaps have been formed with a sharp (deep) U-shape, and when you want to put the kukri into the sheath, you have to have one hand hold both straps while your other hand places the kukri in the sheath - a pain in the butt. So, I decided to nourish not only those straps but all of the leather, with a generous amount of "Bick 4 Leather Conditioner", and I worked the straps back and forth while massaqging them with the Bick'a, to make them more supple and easier to deal with.

BTW - I also have a KA-BAR brand USMC knife, the one with the plain (unserrated) blade and the compressed leather, and I have no intention of actually using it, just because it's so darn purdy and I don't want to mess it up. I keep it just for display - a piece of American history. The KA-BAR folks know how to make great knives (and I have no problem whatsoever with the kurki made in the democratic republic of Taiwan - please don't confuse Chinese crap with Taiwanese-made merchandise, they're worlds apart).

reviewText:
My wife and I have been wearing these in competition for a week now. Its a bit of a pain to set up, but the product works very well and seems to be quite accurate.  One of the best features is that you can put in the length of your stride so that it will calculate an estimate of the distance you have walked.

I struggle a bit to justify the $25 price when theres nothing smart about the product, and pedometers can be found at much lower prices.  It will not sync with a phone, no Bluetooth, etc.  I didn't expect that for a $25 product, but I do expect a lot from a $25 pedometer.

Overall, though, its a great way to measure exercise, calories burned, distance walked, steps taken, etc.

reviewText: I bought this to shape 4 new cue tips.  The first one worked great - perfect dime shape and fast.  The second one took about twice as long to shape as the first. I had to stop after 5 minutes because it was taking way too long and I wasn't seeing any progress.  Needless to say I got a less than perfect shape on that tip.  I bought this because reviews were saying it lasted a long time.  Not in this case.  Maybe to maintain an already shaped tip.  But if you're looking to shape new tips, this just doesn't seem to last.  That said, the scuffer and pick work like a charm on my already-shaped cue tips.  Great for holding chalk.  Maybe go with the Willard shaper for new tips and keep this in the case for maintenance.

reviewText:
I loved this light weight filter!  I recently took it on a week long trip across the Sierra Nevada range - Lone Pine to Sequoia. It worked perfectly!

TIP: I did not use the included squeeze bag, but attached it to a 1 liter club soda bottle instead.  I would just dip the bottle into the stream, put on the filter, and drink/filter as I walked.  This is a great time saver.  (Note: Release air from drinking bottle between squeezes.)

PROS:
+ Very light weight (can be kept in a day pack for emergencies)
+ Very easy to use.  You may need to read directions to purge it, but I think you can figure that out too.
+ Fits standard soda bottles
+ Easy maintenance with purging syringe.

CONS:
- The more expensive model with the pop-up nipple is easier to open and close without your hands. This one requires two hands to open.
- Don't use with heavy sediment.  There is no pre-filter, so limited for clearer water.

BOTTOMLINE:
I'd recommend this to anyone.  It's so light, I keep it in my desert day pack just in case I run out of my supply. It flows well and my backpack buddy used it for 3 weeks straight on the John Muir Trail last year.  Great, inexpensive gift for yourself or your backpacking relatives.
Perfect

I wanted a good EDC knife, and this fits the bill.  It's totally ambidextrous, which for me as a lefty, it's what I need.  AUS 8 steel is a solid metal for knives.  The build quality here is very nice. The blade movement is tight, with no wobble, but still easy to move.  The blade came very sharp out of the box, and has maintained its edge.  The handle is a good fit for medium to large hands.  I am very pleased with it.

The Benjamin Marauder .25 is my second PCP air rifle, the other is an Airforce Condor in .22.  I try to buy "Made in America" as much as I can!!!

I have been into airguns for many many years.  I still have and use a 30+ year old Benjamin 342 multi pump.  PCPs are a whole new level.

The Marauder is relatively powerful, quiet...and can be made quieter with some legal aftermarket products.  Accuracy is excellent, with no need to develop special holds like the "artillery hold" that is popular with spring or nitro guns.  Just shoot them like any other "real" rifle you have experience with.  Aim small, miss small.  With ammo scarce and expensive, this rifle is good to keep your skills up.  Fundamentals are the same.  Breath control, squeeze, bang...or pop as these things go.

8 round magazine is nice, as my Condor is single shot.  Having a quick follow up shot is nice if you use it for hunting...and this rifle can be used for hunting.  Game as large as coyotes have been taken.  Personally I would not be comfortable taking a coyote, but if my skills were better  and I could be assured of a humane kill I would if I was hunting coyote.  Some folks have the skills and have done so.

Now I haven't shot anything but paper with my rifle.  This is just to inform about the power level of this rifle.  It is not a toy, but an adult air rifle.  Make sure you have a good backstop and be aware of what is behind whatever you are shooting at.  I have read on the forums of guys taking ground squirrels and birds at 100+ yards.

The barrel is a high quality American product.  I have heard the .177 and .22 barrels are a bit of a hit and miss.  Some are great others not so good.  There are folks making aftermarket barrels for those rifles though if you buy one of those and get a lemon.

I recommend a Hill or FX pump if you are going to hand pump.  It is not hard, just use your legs like doing shallow squats.  I pump mine up during commercial breaks LOL.  Heat is the enemy of pumps, so just take it slow, pause at the top of the stroke as well as the bottom.  With all the valving, you want to make sure each chamber has a chance to fill before pumping.

You can use any rifle scope you have as well.  Springers or nitro guns need airgun rated scopes as the double recoil will kill even the most expensive rifle scope.  These guns are safe for any scope you have laying around.

I recommend this rifle if you are doing pest control or small game hunting.  It uses more air than a .177 or .22 so if you are just punching holes in paper you might consider another caliber.  You will get more shots per fill on a smaller caliber.

This is a good jacket for its intended use that is built to last. It's not the lightest and smallest but compresses down to easily fit in a jersey pocket (but don't plan on anything other than your house key in with it). The windstopper fabric reduces wind chill about 95%, and, even without any vents, the material is remarkably breathable so you aren't marinating in your own juices at the top of a climb. I can adequately regulate temperature by slightly opening the zipper pulling up the cuffs a bit (cuffs have both elastic and velcro so comfortable and will stay put). I wouldn't want to depend on this jacket in an extended downpour, but it has kept me dry in occasional showers and on a long ride in mist and drizzle on the Blue Ridge Parkway.

It's a good fit for general cycling but not super form fitting; however, this allows adequate room for layering and year-round use and it's comfortable off and on the bike. I'm 6', 175 lbs and find the large true to size with adequate length in the sleeves and tail. I can wear it over my soft-shell cycling jacket in winter but it isn't excessively loose over just a summer jersey. There is some wind noise on the descents but it doesn't puff up like a parachute. Another good example of quality and versatility I've found in most of the Gore Bike products.

reviewText:
The first thing to say here is that this is not a knife. It is plastic, so it will not cut like steel. You don't expect to cut steak with a plastic knife the same as you would with a metal knife, so keep that is mind if you are thinking about buying one of these.

That said, this is a sharp plastic knife. I wanted to check out Cold Steel's Night Shade series and after watching a few YouTube reviews, along with reading up here on Amazon, I though this one would be the best buy. I was not disappointed.

It is VERY light. It has a good grip, easy to maneuver in your hand. I easily ripped up the cardboard box it came in, by both piercing and slashing it. The knife stabs very well, and it slashed much better than I thought it would. I am very impressed with this plastic knife and plan to buy more of them.

It can be easily hidden, without worrying too much about the kids finding it. They can handle the "blade" without getting cut. It is great for using as a practice knife too, and it will do more damage that Cold Steel's rubber trainers.

There were a few cons that took a star away. The first was the metal ring attached. There was not real point to this. It made using the ring on the knife harder to use and was a pain to get off.

The one I got did have a few dents in it, but not enough to send back. The tip was bent a little, but after cutting up the box, it was back in shape looking great.

If you are wanting to hang this up as decoration, it looks cheap, in my opinion.

The grip is as good as you would expect for the price. I will likely put some griping tape on mine.

The design is great, and I would love to see an all metal version of this knife, but as plastic it is really just good for training and/or easily stashed defensive weapon (as it is advertised to be).
summary: Great knife design for a plastic knife

I am a Cold Steel fan. My son deployed in 06 with a bag o' knives to trade and use in the sandbox. I have at least 10 CS blades in my heavy use collection.
  This ain't no grass whip. Fine around camp, only an unusual woodcrafter  would " lash this to a pack ".
Requires bending for close to ground work. Efficient. WELL MADE. Sturdy. Came sharp and well tempered, contact with overgrown chicken wire didn't damage edge.
  Grass whip will be more efficient for most,  a fine idea for the shed, cabin, rv, or to pack to a long term camp MAYBE.
Mine lives on the back porch where it will remain good but not great.
  But this if you spend time camping and like woodscaping. Ugly fat American here, just not that invasive. Meh.
For hunters who need to clear blinds and such, perhaps.
  Take their special forces shovel for a hard a on your back tool with used car beyond clearing a blind or tent site, my opinion.

I have a ton of Park Tools that I use for my bikes...love them.

This pump is a silver turd.  I like that the head for the pump is set up for both schrader and presta valves but that is where the praises stop.

The first thing I noticed was the lack of balance due a design that is top heavy with a poor foot design.  Then I used it and the response is spongy and depending on pressures (MTB vs road) sometimes it gives you an instant reading while a lot of times the handle has to be depressed to the floor with pressure behind it to get a reading.  Annoying but I lived with it.

Now I can't get it to seat deep enough on the presta valves so that I can inflate my tires.  It has gone from bad to worse during this past month.

6 months later Amazon is taking it back.  I am going to use my refund to buy what I had before: a Specialized floor pump.
summary: I love Park Tools but this pump SUCKS!

reviewText: super warm and fluffy, while very compressible, just what I wanted

I would recommend this helmet to anyone doing regular biking.  It has met all the safety standard in place and you can't beat the price.  It came with about 4 extra sponge pads with weak adhesive so they don't stick. Fortunately for me, I didn't need them anyway. As is, it looks good (not like the kind I had and still see at the big box stores, looking like a huge ball on your head). It has a low and narrow profie.

I wasn't sure how a lipguard that doesn't let you custom mold it by heat would work but I'm guessing maybe it's not really needed after trying this out.

The Shock Doctor 3300 Max Air Flow Lipguard truly does allow max air flow.  I imagine this product is designed mostly with American Football in mind but I believe it will work well with any impact related sports and I will be using this while I do "leg day" for weight training.  Sometimes we grind our teeth subconsciously while doing strenuous activities, even while we actively try not to, it just happens.  Gritting and grinding...it's just not good for the teeth and we sometimes need mouthguards.  The Shock Doctor 3300 works very well.  Fits in the mouth quite comfortably and allows unrestricted mouth breathing if needed.  Comes with a tether as well.

I have a slight overbite which I personally (if not naively) think most people have and this lipguard fits comfortably.
summary: Let's me grunt and grit my teeth!

I made the mistake of pushing the trigger assuming it wouldn't be charged out of the box. My ears were ringing for a few seconds. This thing is loud and will get the attention of vehicles. You can adjust the loudness of the horn with a small knob. However, it will be very loud for pedestrians on a normal trail. I usually just have a bluetooth speaker playing music for people to hear me coming. My intention was to catch the attention of cars due to some near misses. I believe this thing will make people look around for where the noise came from. Good addition. Comes with everything you need to mount. My uncle brought a similar knife back from India after WWII, I loved it and used it for clearing brush near the back border of the family yard. I really missed it so when this came up as such an affordable price I jumped on it. It is the dullest knife I have ever purchased, I can fix that. The handle is clunky, shaped correctly but crude compared to the original. The weight and balance are similar to the original and I am no longer young and strong enough to clear brush, so I will probably never wield this one the way I did the original (the original arrived razor sharp and never had to be touched up the steel was so hard) so it will go on the shelf and remind me of my uncle, who was also my godfather. Great memories, just barely OK knife.

The Solo Stove Titan and Solo Pot 1800 combo is a must. Both very stylish; the only logos on them are the words "Solo Stove" in small letters. The pot and the stove itself each come in a black waterproof travel bags. It's possible for both to be in their separate travel bags, and still put the stove inside the pot for traveling, and that way it doesn't rattle around inside the pot. The stove itself seems very durable. Most of the parts (like the handles) can be taken off, so cleaning is easy and if one breaks, it could be replaced. The cooking ring is very durable - the tabs that hold the pot up are strong enough that I was unable to bend them when I tried. The only instructions that come with the pot are a vague overview of what to do written on the box, so I suggest you read many reviews of how other people use it to get some tips.

Here is how I lit the stove:
The first thing I did was collect a pile of twigs and thin branches. Dry wood is a must - the fire will be less smoky, and it will burn more efficiently. Where I live there is about a foot of snow on the ground, and it snows or rains often, so it can sometimes be difficult to find dry wood. I suggest looking for dead branches on trees that are sheltered from rain due to the higher branches. I collected twigs that ranged from the diameter of a match to the diameter of a pencil for about five minutes, creating a fairly decent pile of sticks. Make sure you keep them dry not putting your pile directly on the ground or somewhere where they can get moist.

Next, I assembled my solo stove on a flat rock, and arranged the smallest of my twigs on the wire grate inside the stove. I used a little bit of dryer lint underneath the twigs to act as my tinder, but if you don't have any, then extremely dry, crushed up leaves, a fluffed up piece of grape vine, or birch bark shavings are also great tinder materials. It is also possible to just light the twigs themselves if they are small enough, in which case you don't need tinder. Make sure your pile is accessible and ready to go, broken into pieces a few inches long so that you can add more twigs to feed the fire and keep it going. With one match, I was able to get my fire started and roaring high above the top of the stove in ten seconds. I added more twigs, beginning with the thinner ones, and then adding the thicker ones once the fire became big enough.

Once the fire was started, I put the cooking ring and my pot of water on the stove. I kept the fire roaring by adding more twigs about every 20 seconds. You may be able to get away with adding them less frequently if you add thicker twigs, or if you don't want the fire to be so high that it's practically engulfing the bottom of the pot. By keeping the fire that high the whole time, I was able to boil 32 oz of water (4 cups) in about seven minutes, and had my Ramen cooked and eaten within 15 minutes of starting to collect twigs. I didn't use all of the twigs in my pile, but it's better to have more than you need than to have to scramble around while you are cooking, trying to find more fuel.

Overall, I was impressed and happy with this stove. Sure, it takes a little more effort than simply turning on a gas camping stove, since you have to feed more twigs into it every so often, but not using bottles of fuel saves space and weight in your pack, and you don't have to worry about running out of fuel, unless you are camping in the desert, frozen tundra, or on the ocean. The fact that the stove fits inside the pot also saves a lot of room, and the pot is a great size for making meals for two or more, so if you don't camp alone, you will want a pot this large anyway.

Cleaning the stove and pot was easy. Since I kept my fire big, the bottom of my pot was covered in soot. Most of the soot wiped right off with some water and a paper towel, and almost all of what didn't easily wipe off came off after some scrubbing. The stove changed colors a little and looks a little scorched where the heat touched it the most, but I think it looks better that way. What I was really surprised about was how cool the outside and bottom of the stove stayed, even while the fire was roaring inside. I was able to pick it up and move it, and it was cool enough to touch with bare hands. The pot has handles that pop out that allow you to carry the pot when it's hot - you just have to remember to pop out the handles before the pot gets too hot to touch it.

The only downsides I found: The day after I got the combo, the travel bag for the pot ripped along the seam. The bag seems like such heavy-duty construction, but the seams are apparently very weak. This is nothing a sewing machine can't fix, but I was surprised that it ripped so soon. It wasn't even under any stress - just ripped from being picked up and moved. I hadn't even used the pot yet. Definitely not a deal breaker - it's still a nice, waterproof bag with a nice drawstring - just the seams are a bit weaker than necessary. The only other downside I have found is how soot builds up on the pot because of the wood fire. However, it's fairly easy to get the soot off with just some paper towels and water, and you can search the Internet for many other tips on removing soot if you need to.

Great product! I definitely recommend this combo.
summary: Solo Stove and Pot Combo - Tips

Impossible to beat thermos. two ice cubes and over night there will still be some solid ice in the morning. I make sure to measure the temp of coffee before putting in because it cools so slowly you won't be able to drink for HOURs if it's piping hot to start. 130-140 F is the temp I put my coffee in and it will be perfect drinking temp for 2-3 hours. You need to remove the blue seals periodically to clean them or your water will smell like cofee; I use some pure alcohol; everclear is good vs rubbing since it's food safe. I used to have the  plain stainless but love my new upgraded. It says it's 18oz but it only holds about 17.8. I just went through and posted a comment on a majority of the ignorant 1-star reviews that complained about leaking; the leaking is almost always caused from operator error; usually from over-tightening the lid; it takes about 1/12 of a turn of the lid to completely tighten this lid; more will damage the seal and either destroy it or make it fall out.

Packaging Each barrel cleaner came in its own clear plastic zip lock type bag with product label and identification for the caliber of firearm to use it with. Product The dimensions of each product is the same of the five calibers I purchased. There are six components to each snake. Each comes with a brass weighted tip attached to about 24 of paracord which is then stitched in the barrel snake fabric which is also about 24" in length. The fabric thickness and width changes for each caliber. The other four segments are a cleaner section, a brush section, a drying section and finally an oil section. You can find numerous videos online to instruct you on the proper techniques and products to use for this process. Conclusion I love the simplicity of the barrel snake system and design. They are relatively inexpensive so you can buy one for each caliber of firearm you have. I like the fact that you can clean the snakes to keep them in good condition for your next use (recommend placing them in a tight laundry sack for delicates before placing them in the washing machine). Full disclosure, I love to shop on amazon and I always look at customer reviews and the number of stars for the review total average before purchasing a product. Since I rely heavily on others reviews, I am always honest in my reviews, and try to always leave feedback to help others when making a purchase. I have fully tested and inspected this product and my review is based on my experience with this product. If you found this review to be helpful please click yes at the bottom of my review and if you have any additional questions always feel free to ask.

reviewText:
Purchased for my wife to use on a casting rod I built for her.  She had never used a casting rod before so I thought that using a left-hand retrieve would be good for her.  That part is fine.  She has used this reel on freshwater only and it has been bathed in reel-magic several times.

However, I've not been impressed with the reel.  It worked OK for the first year or so, but over the past 6 months it has progressively gotten worse about not recovering from a cast sequence by turning the handle.  What I mean by this, after you push the button, make the cast, and then start reeling it won't "click in" to start turning the spool.

I looked it up on YouTube and learned how to completely take it apart.  I found that the mechanism that holds a particular plate down so it can catch the button retrieve is worn or the arm that does the pushing is worn.  I was able to improve it's ability to work most of the time, but occasionally it still fails to click in to catch the spool.  This is most annoying when fishing top water lures and you can't get the reel to work when a fish is smacking your lure.

Other than that issue, the reel has functioned as advertised.  My wife really likes the magnetic adjustments and has learned how to get the reel to perform quite well for casting (I'm proud of her!).

However, I will not be buying another Abu Garcia Black Max. Based on working performance I'd give it a 4 or a 5 but from a mechanical performance it's a 1. I have a Shimano Curado bait caster that has been used on saltwater without proper maintenance that is performing 10 times better and is twice as old.  Of course it cost twice as much too!

As I said in the title: You get what you pay for.

Added NOTE:  My wife and I fish more than most. For the first 6 months of this reel's life it was fished with nearly 3 times a week.  Even now it is used about 4 times a month on average. So maybe we used it up faster than Abu Garcia planned?  Still doesn't make me a happy customer.

UPDATE 2/11/15:  The "fix" didn't work very well.  It seems to have helped but it still acts up two or three times per fishing trip.  Looks like a new Shimano Curado is on my shopping list.
summary: You get what you pay for

The following is my initial review after only several uses.  I will make updates if my opinion changes or if my machine has quality issues.

Like many people, I considered the top rowers available (Concept2 and WaterRower) before purchasing this ProRower.  I have used the Concept2 in gyms many times, so I was familiar with that machine.  I had never previously tried any water based rowing machine.  I decided to go with a water machine based on the noise and feel of the Concept2 compared to the many reviewers opinion on water based machines.  I wanted something quieter and more relaxing.

Having narrowed my search to a water machine, I considered price and ease of movement of the machine.  The WaterRower was significantly more expensive that the ProRower.  In addition, the WaterRower was heavier and larger (we move our rower in front of our TV to use it and store it in a back room when not in use so low weight and size are key).

So far I'm very happy with my purchase.  I can confirm that I prefer using a water based rower over the air based Concept2.  Its MUCH quieter, and the smoothness really helps me get into a rhythm.  As stated by many reviewers, even with the max water in the tank, the resistance is not as high as what can be achieved with the Concept2.  However, it is more than adequate and provides a decent challenge (I row for 1 hour sessions, without interval training and it is tiring).

The ProRower arrived in two boxes, approximately 90% assembled.  It was by far the easiest to assemble workout equipment I've bought (compared to 2 ellipticals and a treadmill).  It takes at most 30 easy minutes to assemble and begin rowing.  The machine is very solid in use and gives the impression that it will last a long time.  Certainly the bungee recoil cord appears to be the weak link.  If I have any issues I will post an update.  The display is large and easy to read and suites my purposes by displaying time and strokes, the metrics I prefer for gauging my effort level.

Filled to max water capacity, the machine is somewhat heavier than I was hoping, but still light enough to roll around on carpet and into another room.  It stands up very easily and in that position takes up very little space.

On the whole, this appears to be a good value for a solid rowing machine and I would recommend it to anyone.
summary: Great rower at a good value.

I believe I went with the smaller version and it's still 9ft long. I suppose if you want two people in it then it could be small, but just don't do that with the small version. My buddy is ordering one soon after seeing mine in action and even taking a nap in it himself.

A truly awesome backpack for cycling or general use -- it has all the technical pack features without the extra bulk or things you don't need like ski pole holders and waist-strap pockets. The frame is extremely stiff, and unless the backpack is packed to the absolute brim, the suspension system will keep the pack off your back, i.e. airflow is excellent. Side mesh pockets are generously sized (fits a 1-liter Nalgene bottle perfectly), includes a nifty rain cover (all packs should have this), and a surprisingly functional helmet lock. Also has vented shoulder straps, generous main compartment, laptop "sleeve" nestled right in the frame, and the bright green color is vivid and snappy. It almost defies gravity how comfortable this backpack is -- with the right adjustments, a full load seems to float off your back and evenly distribute on your shoulders: imagine the difference between somebody pulling you backward from behind and having a load evenly distributed directly downward through your feet. I'll say it again: this backpack is hilariously comfortable, you almost want to wear it just to wear it. Also, has a lifetime warranty. If I had to leverage a complaint, it would be that the Osprey logo is kind of big and dorky -- a more minimalist approach would've been fresher. Really though, totally satisfied with this product.
summary: A truly awesome backpack for cycling or general use -- it has ...

It worked on my CZ 75 PO1- rear sight only.  The front sight you need to tap out the roll pin and punch out the sight forward- not sideways.  On the rear sight be very careful to  follow the instructions from both from the tool maker and sight maker especially when it comes to filing to fit before inserting the new sight. I used blue painters masking tape to hold the cut credit card pieces along the slide frame to keep from marring the slide. I purchased the front and rear sights from Cajun Gun works. The front sight comes with a specialized sight removal punch and replacement roll pin.  You don't reuse the roll pins.
The only issue I had is that it took a little time going back and forth until I got the sight centered. This was due to my lack of experience not the tool.  It you are like me and you never installed sights before or tangled with roll pins be patient and buy the correct tools for the job.
I don't know if this help- I don't think it hurt.  After filling the base of the new sight to a close fit.  I put the sight in the freezer to shrink it befor pressing it on to the slide.
Since I am a novice I need to purchase a few items from Amazon for the project.
This Sight-Tool.com Gen 4.  Outstanding tool by the way and American made!
Can of Kroil penetrating oil.  Soak the factory sight if stubborn.
Set of roll pin punches and roll pin holders.  I purchased metric punches for my CZ.
Loctite Thread Locker Blue 242.
Good Luck!

I have sadly been acquiring random satchels/sling packs over the last 10 years...  Various brands and slightly varying styles.
This is by far the best one yet.  I will admit I was a little concerned about the large plastic side release buckle, because it's quite honestly the only thing in the picture of the OD version that looked cheap...  Boy was I wrong.  I quickly reminded myself when I opened the packaging that this epic pack wasn't going to be used to hold anything more than a single days worth of gear for casual hikes, scouting or as a grab n' go light weight pack for short road trips.  If the military look is what your looking for and are a student, this could be _the_ pack for your entire stint through school.  No joke, this pack is robust.
Fully ambidextrous, which for me as a Lefty, this was a huge turn on and one of my biggest complaints with previous purchases.
The shoulder strap is comfortable and adjustable.  The Handle is strong enough and the general stitching is top notch that if I filled this bag full of bricks and started swingin', I wouldn't have anything to worry about.  ;)  So don't worry about the weight with this bad boy.  If you can fit it inside and the zippers close, your golden.
The cross body security strap is adjustable and keeps this pack snug to the body as your traversing obstacles, generally in motion and even felt secure enough under a light jog without feeling out of control or losing anything.  Even under a stressed run, the pack shifted ever so slightly, but was still secure and comfortable.
Drain holes are a bonus and actually well done.  Located in both main compartments.
There are seriously all bases covered on this pack when you sit and seriously consider all the thought that went into each elastic strap, molle points, the blind zippers, key ring strap, etc.
Total empty weight is 1.5lbs (680g)
***
As awesome as it is, there are 2 flaws with this pack though.  Both of which are unable to be seen in the advertising pictures.
The first one is the choice of plastic clips that is attached to the end of the shoulder strap, which clips to the lower D-rings on either side of the pack.  The hinged design is completely unnecessary and only introduces another failure point in the design.
Even though it is the same heavy duty injection molded plastic as the D-rings & side release buckles, the single point clip design and sewn strap provides enough flexibility.  The swivel design is failure point enough.
Secondly, at the very bottom of the pack, where the edge piping is stitched all the way around the pack, where the two ends meet, is the ONLY place on this entire pack that is stitched horribly.
As your looking and feeling the pack in your hands... Epppiiicccc, and then, s*** the bed...  Really?  Your going to finish the stitching on these beautiful and durable packs as if a 5 year old operating a sewing machine for the first time wrapped it up?!
However, even with its flaws, I absolutely love this pack.
If the applications I've listed above are right up your ally, this is the pack for you.
Huh?  What?  20 USD??????  Inconceivable...  You couldn't even buy the plastic components and zippers for that price, let alone the rest of the material, let alone this quality assembled sling pack.  Oh wait, you can. ;)
summary: Great bag doesn't even cover it...
