IT'S MISLABELED -- IT AIN'T 43 INCHES LONG!  I read other reviewers' complaints about this, but figured it would be OK for my Mossberg MMR Hunter with a 20-inch barrel, which measures 38.75 inches.  I was right, my rifle fits, but there is not even a half-inch to spare.  This bag is only 41 inches long on the outside (at the spine), and 39 inches long on the inside.  Even if you measure diagonally from corner to corner (which makes zero sense), it is still only 42 inches.  Bottom line:  IF YOUR RIFLE IS LONGER THAN 39 INCHES, IT WILL NOT FIT.

If your gun is 39 inches or less, this is a very high quality bag, I believe.  The pockets are fine for AR-15 standard 30-round mags, even with  MagPul rubber magazine assist gizmos.  They are just a bit tight, but that's good, the mags won't slide out on their own.  But the pockets are definitely too tight for an AK.  The sling attaches at the wrong points for comfortable carry, but I don't need it, I use the handles to go the 100 yards from car to range.

I haven't had this case long enough to vouch for its endurance, but it seems well-made, the zippers seem strong, so I believe it will last a good long while.

This is the original Folding Firebox woodburning folding stove, bundled together with an optional accessory, the large size Grill Plate. Combined is cheaper than buying separately.

Designed and made in USA. Sturdy, durable, well built, almost indestructible. Holds very heavy pots with ease. Stable. Can be configured several different ways for various conditions. Clever (brilliant) design. Totally different from most other woodburning stove designs.

Great for camping, also for disaster preparedness. Works just fine using twigs, bark, wood scraps, pretty much anything flammable. All that's left behind is white ash. Eco-friendly. "Leave no trace "  philosophy.

Helpful videos and user tips on the maker's website. I love mine. Also makes a great backyard barbecue grill.

Firebox also offers other bundled stove-plus-accessories packages. Worth checking those out also.
summary: Folding Hinged Stainless Steel Camping Woodburning Stove. Versatile and Tough

Star Rating: When I do a review I always start out with 5 stars . Then if there is something wrong I will deduct one star and explain why. This way Im not just arbitrarily picking a number. I do NOT ever give good feedback for bad products. Rest assured my reviews are honest. If you have any questions about this product or my review, please do not hesitate to ask. I can help you determine if this will fit your needs. Thanks for reading.

I bought my first of these knives in 2012. Thanks to Amazon's meticulous record keeping, I now realize I own 6 of these.

Let's be realistic. The purpose of this knife is to be the cheapest possible fixed blade knife. And you know what? This really is just that.
"So, what is it?"
-It's essentially what's known as a knife "blank" with some braided nylon cordage (NOT paracord) wrapped around the grip.

"Will you need to sharpen it?"
-You bet. It's under 10 bucks, so you should expect that.

"Is the sheath terrible?"
-Pretty much. It holds the knife and ferro rod,  but there's no retention and the durability is just "ok."

"Is that "serrated" or "saw" spine just aesthetic?"
-Sure is. It's not useful for anything. At all. Probably should have been left plain but this is what the designer decided to go with and people are buying it. More power to 'em.

"How durable is it?"
-I'd say "Surprisingly unbreakable." It's a cheap stainless steel, most likely a 440 because that seems to be the cheapest material these days. BUT it's thick enough (about 1/8") and a simple design. I haven't managed to break one via normal (but by no means gentle) use. And being stainless, it refuses to rust.

"Will it take/keep a good edge?"
-From a knife snob perspective, not really. It won't split atoms, but it's able to get plenty sharp for normal outdoor knife use. I'll usually sharpen it after about 3 or 4 trips out into the woods. Your mileage may vary, but again...this is a knife that you can get for under 10 bucks.

"What are the dimensions/weight?"
-I have yet to put one on a scale or micrometer. If you really want me to, I'll do it (just leave a comment). Overall length is 11" like the description says. Cutting edge (as you can see) is less than half that due to the finger choil.

"Is the ferro rod worth it?"
-YES! In fact, you can find other "fire steels" of this size for about 10 bucks...and they don't come with a knife! The rod is about 1/4" thick (again, haven't measured) and about 2 inches long. I've worn through almost half of the first one I got (well over a hundred of successful fires) and the plastic end still hasn't broken or popped off.

"Would you trust it as your only knife?"
-Not only would I, I have many times. I keep a couple in emergency kits now, but back in '12 I carried this knife with me on all my overnights in the woods. That thing has chopped a lot of wood - even batoning. It's now been retired, but only because I've long since upgraded. I'd still rely on it in a heartbeat.

This is not the first Thermos brand vacuum bottle I've owned. We have several. All of them have been excellent and perform as the manufacturer claims. They are very sturdy and we've had no problems with any of them, whatsoever.

However, to get the claimed time hot or cold you -do- need to prepare the thermos as per directions. If you want it to stay hot, rinse it out with hot tap water then let it stand full of hot tap water until you are ready to fill it with coffee or whatever. Then dump out the tap water and fill it with your drink or soup etc. It will stay hot as claimed. That is our experience with them.
The same applies to cold. Fill it with cold water and put it in the fridge awhile. How we do it in summer is to clean it and fill with cold water the night before and put in the fridge, then the next morning dump our the water and fill with whatever you want to keep cold. If it's water... then fill it with your filtered water and put it in the fridge then use the next day.

If you refuse to preheat or precool it will till keep your food hot or cold but probably not for as long. The laws of physics are what they are. :-)

I am a security guard so I have to carry pepper spray (and would do so anyway), and Sabre is a reputable brand.  I however really would rather have had a flip top safety than the twist safety.  The quick release keychain doesn't like to release all that quickly, in fact if you don't have long fingernails in order to poke deep inside the groove where the latch is, you may find yourself entirely unable to get the thing free.  This could be disastrous in a self defense situation where you need to bring it up quickly.  I'd suggest doing away with the key ring and putting it in your pocket, or swapping the release connector for velcro.  I eventually replaced this with something else closer to what I prefer, but it served me for about a year, where I thankfully never needed to use it.

I also never cared for the perfectly round design.  In the dark you may not be able to tell where the business end is.  It would be better if it had an oval design or finger grooves.  If you work in security I'd suggest getting a carrying pouch for it.  If you just want something for self defense, it's fine, but test out methods of quickly drawing it before relying upon it.  Still it's better than nothing, but whoever designed the canister and carrying method needs to rethink it from the perspective of someone who might actually have to use it.
Drips
summary: Only vertical use cause it drips

I have used it to catch about 800 rounds so far from a 9mm P226 Sig and a 1911 45 ACP.

It takes some setting up and height adjustments. I shoot on a lane table and this catcher takes up a fair bit of the limited space, but it does not get in my way. I often have to put wood blocks under it to have it catch and although it gets close to 100% once things are set up, a few find their way elsewhere. It is also sensitive to how many shells are in the net especially when elevated as the net is pulled taught and ejected shells hit the back of the net and bounce out.

It was a little confusing on how to assemble the net notably the attaching the back stop mechanism.

Sometimes I wish I could take off the 'A' frame and use something of my own making to conserve bench space, but this isn't a big deal and I can remove it, but it will mean taking a hacksaw to the 'A' frame because it is welded to the rectangular cross piece.

It's not a bad net, but it requires some fine tuning and periodic shell removal to keep it working well. In my case I would guess that I would have to clean it at between 75-100 9mm shells to prevent the net from throwing ejected cartridges back out.

It does keep the brass clean. You have to reach in the net to pick out the shells. There is no draw string at the back to dump them at one time.  (Remember to was those hands after leaving the shooting area to prevent lead and Hg poisoning)/

I have always used this net on a bench and have not tried a tripod which will not work well in a bench environment.

Coming from a family of mostly boys and Big Wheel lovers, I know these current low riding Big Wheels are not the same quality as my little brother's Big Wheel from 1971. My brother loved his Big Wheel so much, that my son also had to have one when he was 3. Even though he was too small, he didn't care- walking it was just as good as riding it.

Things haven't changed much in the design, the big wheel bikes are all still too large for children under 4-5, but the quality has changed a lot for the original Big Wheel. After replacing the back seat 3 times, the original current Big Wheel of our nephew's recently went to the garbage. Replacing the Big Wheel with a tricycle was even worse- after a couple turns- the head injuries even with a helmet proved to be going from a cheap big wheel to bruises.

This Radio Flyer Deluxe Big Flyer is very similar to the Big Wheel of the seventies- very sturdy. The seat doesn't break at the pegs like the current Big Wheel. It is still too large for children under 5, but they don't care- they enjoy just having it, even if they have to walk it. They use their feet anyway for braking, so they don't mind walking it until their feet reach the pedals. My son walked his Big Wheel for a year before he could reach the pedals.

The best thing about this Radio Flyer Deluxe Big Flyer is our nephews love it. Taking the fastest high speed turns ends up in falls inches from the ground- meaning less painful minor injuries. My brother and son never had a bad injury being so close to the ground and this was in the days of no head protection. Putting it together was not difficult with the directions and once together, it's hard to keep the kids off. It's nice to see Radio Flyer keeping the tradition of making a sturdy Big Flyer that is perfect for 4 to 7 year olds, just like in the seventies when things were built to last.
summary: Big Flyer Is Sturdy, Safe & Our Boys Favorite

reviewText: I got this clip for my Ka-Bar Becker Necker sheath.  It is very secure.  The retainer tab on the clip does not allow the clip to back off your belt accidentally.  It keeps the sheath close to my body so I can't snag it on stuff and holds the sheath steady when I resheath my knife.  The spring steel of the clip holds its shape well.  My only complaint is that it came with very small Torx head screws which require a very small Torx head wrench that is not in standard Torx wrench selections.  They need to use more common flat head or hex head hardware or provide a appropriate Torx head wrench with the clip.  Be careful not to over tighten the screws because the aluminum grommets will strip out easily.  A drop of Loktite on each screw would be a good idea.

reviewText: Good deal for the price, but the headlight collar is not big enough to fit my road-bike handle bar, but it will fit my mountain bike handle bar. To make it fit my road-bike, I hand to use electrical tape.  I used it one time for a commute from my home to the bus stop on streets without any street lighting.  I live at the top of a hill and  where I  have to essentially ride my brakes half down and avoid allot of irregularities in the road.way.  Though this light is pretty bright, the pattern was not wide spread enough to give me a comfortable feeling.  I either had to have it directed way out in front and not be able to see anything in the 0' to 20' range, or point it down to light up right in front of me and not see anything way out in front.  It was very uncomfortable feeling which I won't be repeating.  Now looking for a light that has good coverage close and far, but am realizing that will probably cost 5 to 10 times more than this light, which is probably a good deal if helps prevent me crashing.
summary: Great price, but didn't fit my road-bike, or have a wide enough spread of light.

I purchased an 18 ounce classic and the cap fit a little too snug, squeezing the gasket a little much on the opposite of the hinge side. I bent the two vertical loops on that side that are right at the bottle about 1mm (1/16") up with a common pair of pliers. The lid now fits perfectly. The one from the Cabelas bottle I used to replace the cap on an older klean kanteen. A beat up blue painted model. These will remove the paint around the rim and may scratch the bottle but it fits in just fine with all of the scratches and dents that show that this a well loved bottle. I also had to adjust this cap in the same way as the other. This cap also was offset a bit to the rear. I increased the angle of the hinge where it comes off of the cap a wee bit and it is now centered. These caps are great and I hope that I was able to help all those folks that had poorly fitting caps. I would just like to see some replacement gaskets offered so I can get rid of the one with the metal markings from the Cabelas  bottle that went into the  recycling bin.

I have owned this pack for 2 years now and use it regularly for day hikes with my kids. This backpack is very well made with plenty of MOLLE attachment points.

Only two minor gripes.
1. This pack could use a chest strap.
2. I had to sew one of the straps a bit as it looked like it was coming detached from the pack. This could be a deal breaker for some. I simply look at it as inevitable and part of gear maintenance.

Highly recommended. This pack should last you a very long time.

reviewText:
These Peltor Sport Electronic Hearing Protector Tactical 300 work very well and fit my huge head very comfortably! We own a gun shop and indoor range and also run a lot of firearm training classes, so have a lot experience with hearing protection. Here are my observations:

Pros -
+ Fit; as noted above I have a very large head and a lot of low end protection just doesn't fit me, but these can be worn all day with ease
+ Attenuation; provides great protection, even when exposed to high calibers at the indoor range
+ Amplification; as a trainer it is very important that I can hear my students and these allow for voices to come through very clearly

Cons -
- None

Overall, these are exceptional hearing protection that work every bit as well as hoped. We also have the Peltor 500, which is a good choice if you want Bluetooth but they are a little heavier.

Highly Recommended!

CFH
summary: Impressive Electronic Hearing Protection - Highly Recommended

Glad I got for my Wife's Grandpa. It is a smooth knife, but it's also a bit stiff at the pivot. I did carry it for 2 days and flicked it open/closed a lot in order to break it in for him. The 3 stars is because I was flipping it open all night breaking it in and the metal filings were coming out from where the pivot is, that is perfectly fine with me because that means it's breaking in and smoothing out, but the orange just seems to absorb the filings and now it looks dirty on the G10 at the thumb studs and axis lock. That kinda sucks cause it's a Christmas present for Gramps. I know I would be mad if it was mine and I never used it and it looked dirty and I couldn't really clean it off.

The Hook had exactly the same problem with looking dirty after breaking it in. The problem I have with the hook is that there isn't much room for your thumb to get the thumb stud. Once the Hook is out, it has quite a bit of wiggle side to side. It's not really a problem, but I'm just letting you people know. It doesn't have a lock bar so it just pushes back into it's home, that might be the cause of the blade play (I'm pretty sure it is). The detent is perfect though if you can get a hold of the thumb stud.

The G10 is kinda ruff so you can have a very sure grip on it, but it's a freaking rescue knife, a good grip should be expected. Though, it may not be the best EDC for a regular person because it is so rough on the pocket. The size is fine, but it does make it a little hard to deploy the blade.
summary: You Should Probably Get The Black Model

Well I received my Boonie pretty quick and purchased this strictly for fishing to keep the sun at bay. And my first impression was this hat is light. It is crushable and will be able to fit in my shoulder bag to go fishing. The brim is approximately 3in all around with a 5 row stitching from the outside edge seam. In high winds it not hold its shape I'm sure. There are no openings in the bucket to escape the heat.  And since it is made in China,  I will assume the hat size dimensions are based on the Chinese people. Because one size fits all is incorrect. I wear a large / xlarge hat based on my melon of around 23.5in. and this fits too snug for me. The elastic cinch rope around my skull is all the way out and still snug for me. I'm hoping I will find a way to expand the size just some so it will be comfortable to wear. I'm sure if I shave my head it will fit fine. But if you have thick hair might be to snug of a fit. Maybe as its worn the size will increase. Because of the too snug fit , I will dock 1 star from this item. And if in the future as its worn and if becomes more comfortable I will update my review.
summary: Very light, but runs small for " one size fits all "

reviewText: This is a well manufactured belt, it is thick enough to hold several belt attachments while not too thick so that you can hold phone cases and other small items.  I use this to holster my Beretta 92 and my dslr camera with zoom lens.  The belt has a pliable plastic insert sandwiched between two layers of nylon 'seat belt' material.  The belt does not sag or bend over, the limitations of this belt is not the belt itself but the belt loops on your pants.  The nylon is smooth and easily slides through belt loops, holsters, cases and anything else.  The buckle is simple to use and is adjustable.  The stitching quality is good with no loose threads and the buckle has a nice satin black finish with no metal burrs. Overall I'm happy with this purchase.  I thought this belt was made in USA which is my preference but it is made in China. Overall, it's a great belt at a great price.
summary: Very good EDC belt with good stitching and craftsmanship. Not made in USA though.

I asked if there were cross beams on the underside mount surface of the riser. Multiple answers implied there were 2. The one I received did not have 2-- the one I received had one of the screws gound flat/flush with the bottom surface, and the other they left plain.  I was hoping that this riser would be well designed and have at least one squared cross beam underneath to counter recoil impact and riser movement.  Alas this riser will work short term, but over time the recoil impacts will eventually move it, and it will chew up the back of one of the pic teeth on your rifle.  Good luck depending on the screw clamps to hold it, but eventually it will shift with recoil.

I returned this pump, but I'm still giving it 5 stars.  When I opened the box, I marveled at two things.  First, it's size, but more importantly, the quality of the build.  This is an awesome, high volume pump that would absolutely be great for pumping inflatables.

The hose, the canister, the heft, all reeks of "the best"  quality and thoughtful construction.  I was tempted to keep it, but my purpose is simply to inflate air mattresses when I go camping.  While this machine would definitely do that better than any I've seen, it's just too big and heavy for easy transport and I'm forced to go with the much lower quality coleman pump.

If I had a house on the water, or a pool, I'd buy this in a heart beat.
summary: Great Pump - But big and heavy.

I have 2 functional trainers in my gym. If you do not know what that is do a search here on amazon and you will find a plethora of machines that are used for weight training that have adjustable arms and settings. For the trainers that do not exceed 100 pounds this model works very well. It allows you to easily change attachments out and it works for every attachment I have better than the biners that these come with. The only exception is plyometrics or explosive exercises with extremely high starting and stopping velocity. For those exercises the standard biners do not work anyway. You have to have a locking biner for those exercises.

I could not imagine using this for keys or something like that so I have no complaint there.
summary: This is one of the best Functional Trainer biners

If I had written this review last night, I would have given the unit 1 star (only because you can't give 0 stars!)  I have been having issues with this chronograph since I purchased it.  It was constantly giving me error messages.  I was rarely ever able to get any useful data.  It made the product basically unusable.  I chalked it up to purchasing an inexpensive unit.  However, after another terrible day with it at the range yesterday, I decided to search and see if there was anything online that addresses my issues with this chronograph.  Lo and behold, Caldwell issued a statement on their website for the chronograph that certain units manufactured right before I purchased mine had faulty sensors and were producing the errors that I was having.  I called the number listed this morning and spoke with a very nice gentlemen.  He asked me a few questions about the issues I was having.  He then asked for my address stating a new model will be delivered to me within 5-7 business days!  I really appreciate a company that looks out for its customers.  I already own several other Caldwell products, but their customer service has now cemented my loyalty to them.  Keep up the good work!

On another note, a friend of mine that has this chronograph, only a little older, loves it and his works flawlessly.  I would not hesitate to recommend this chronograph to anyone, especially with Caldwell's great customer service.
summary: A company that stands behind its products

reviewText:
Pro Edition Wrist Wraps work great when I do the weights up to two pounds.  I suffer from arthritis in my wrists and the exercises I do daily are recommended by my physician to keep them strong without causing too much strain or damage to them.  Wrist wraps were suggested and these work better than the ones I received from the doctor's office.

I can't give an opinion for people lifting heavy weights but for my condition they work perfectly and my physician has seen them and approved them for my use while exercising with my light weights.

My thanks to the manufacture for a sample to try and evaluate; this review gives my honest opinion.
Love

This Burris AR-PEPR QD Scope Mount exceeded my expectations. I used it to mount an 1-4x20 Vortex Viper 300mm to an LMT 5.56. Was within inches out of the box with just a visual bore sight off the bench. Good value. Comes with smooth upper rings and accessory mount rings (like in the pic)

This is my second snugpak sleeping bag, my first one was stolen on deployment, which really pissed me off because it was an awesome bag as well.  I love this bag for a few reasons:
1) High Quality, European Design with Input from SOF Forces in US and UK
2) Super compact-able, will fit anywhere!
3) The warmth you get from this bag is awesome compared to it's size (due to the materials used)
4) Can unzip to open up to a poncho liner/blanket type deal, used on top of bed in deployed location +110 deg outside, 60ish deg inside CHU with AC on so gets cold in my room so it's nice to have this on me
5) Value, Damn this is a great Value!

Cons: MADE IN CHINA :-(

Kills me that this great brand has stuff made in china...designed and headquarted in the UK but made in China, I would pay more if it were made in the US or UK.  But don't let that deter you from getting this bag, it's Awesome! Also for one of the best deployment bags, check out the Snugpak KitMonster 120L, survived 5 deployments with me now and only asks for more!
summary: SnugPak Hit's Another Home Run! 1 Con...

I've carried my Ruger LC9s in this pocket holster daily for over 3 months without any issues.  I work outdoors, and frequently wear cargo shorts or jeans, and I have had no negative issues with this holster.  The only downside, which isn't a big enough deal to knock a star IMO, is that with the open top, and open bottom, if you carry it frequenly in your pocket, you will get some pocket lint build-up on/in your gun.  If you clean your gun like you should, this isn't really an issue.

The outside of the holster has rubber, grippy material to it.  It isn't overly abrasive, and it does soften up some with use, but not enough to where the holster doesn't stay in your pocket when you draw.  The interior material of the holster is soft and protects your firearm well.  So far I have used this in cold temperatures when it was snowing, and 90 degree humid temperatures now where I'm covered in sweat, and I have had no rust problems on my gun from moisture issues with the holster.

I have used Uncle Mikes, Blackhawk, and Maxpedition holsters in the past, and The Nemesis is hands down the best one I've ever owned for daily pocket carry.  I have had no issues with printing that I'm aware of, at least I've never had anybody mention my gun or ask if I was carrying a gun.  The holster is so comfortable in my pocket that I hardly even notice it is there most of the time, which could actually be a problem, as I've accidentally carried my gun in a few places that I shouldn't have because I completely forgot I had it in my pocket.

reviewText:
My wife and I typically ride after work and that means in the dark during the winter months.

As we ride in SoCal in a residential area, we need to be seen by cars and that is the major objective of using the lights.

In the pulse mode, you stick out like a sore thumb. If they can't see you then they are either blind drunk or shouldn't be driving.

Despite the fact the lights are not sold as providing adaquate illumination for you to ride by, I find they throw enough light to get about 2 second view of things in your path. You may not know what it is but you did see enough to get around the object.

It was a snap to install them.

reviewText:
I bought these darts hoping they would be small enough for my cheapie home dart board. Sadly, they're still too heavy, but that's hardly the fault of the darts. I decided to take these to dart night at the bar, I only switched to then because I really wanted to try them out and I couldn't use them at home. I have never looked back. I love these darts. I love the fatter barrel for gripping. The only real wear has been the finish rubbing off on the grip area, but I play probably 20 or 30 games a week with them. I'm planning to order more in another color. Almost everyone who has tried them has gone on to get a set of their own.
Be aware that they won't fit in a case with slim pockets. I use a case with foam slots to hold the darts. If these will be your only set that you use to have on occasion (thus you won't need a larger multi set case) be sure to get a case decided to hold Bumblebee style darts. You can also spend a little more to get the ones with spinning shafts, those are what I'm getting next.

This is the best case lube for resizing brass.  It's not messy at all, and minimizes resistance between the case and the die.  I load about 250 pieces of brass in a gallon zip-lock bag, give a few sprays of One-Shot, and shake everything around for about 20 seconds.  Quick and easy case lubing.  Just be sure not to inhale the fumes and do your best to minimize skin contact.

I love this yoga bag! It fits my new yoga mat perfectly. It's not a very thick mat and there's room to spare so I'd have no doubt that the bag will fit a yoga mat of any size. I picked the lilac colored bag and it's every bit as bright and vibrant as pictured. It closes via a drawstring and has an adjustable strap to help carry your yoga mat. Yoga mats can get so dirty, so it's nice to be able to have something that can keep it clean when not being used, or to keep the filth out of your house, stuck in the bag.

The bag has a small sewn-in logo just like it is advertised in the picture. It was packaged simply, but it would make a perfect gift when paired with one of the great yoga mats you can get easily and affordably here on Amazon!

reviewText:
If you already have a good hiking backpack and just need the water bladder & straw, this is a great option. It is relatively inexpensive, easy to clean, easy to fill, and I've had no issues with leaks at all. I had a Thule backpack that came ready to be used as a hydration backpack, but didn't have the bladder. I got this and have gone on a few hikes using it. The size is great. 3L is plenty for even long hikes in a dry climate. If you aren't going that far, you don't have to fill it up as much and you can save on weight. But having the option to get up to 3L is a great for those days when I want to go further.

While they advertise that this can also be recycled instead of cleaned, I found cleaning to be not that difficult. Also, it is still a sturdy bladder, so I see no need to replace it instead of cleaning, even after multiple uses. I will revise the review if I have any issues, but I've used it multiple times and can highly recommend it.
summary: Great water system to use in any backpack

reviewText:
Update:  I added a picture of the bike shorts inside out to show the very substantial seat pad.  In retrospect, I think I would get one size larger, but they still work fine.
***
Got these when my traditional, chamois-like padded bike shorts gave out.  I'm 5'9" (1.8 meters), 160 lbs (72.6 kg), 32"  (81.3 cm) waist and got the Large in these.  Definitely glad I upsized, as recommended! The shorts are still quite snug, but have plenty of spandex in them, so they work just fine when you are riding.  The seat pad is quite prominent and thick and noticeable when you are walking around, but, once you get on a bike, it feels comfortable, and breathes well when riding, and provides good padding.  The ends of the legs are tight and don't ride up at all when pedaling. All in all, a good purchase.  Flat seams, well-stitched, nice white panels on the sides for visibility.  Wish the pad were a little less bulky, but definitely OK with it
summary: snug but good fit, big seat pad, but comfortable when riding

While I haven't took it camping yet as of (05/07/2011) I will next month,I haven't tent camped in a long time and this was my first tent in years. When I unrolled it, it looked kind of hard to put together but actually its a breeze to setup, I considered the Coleman instant tent which was 199 because it looked like it was easy to set up, i'm glad I saved the extra $100 and got this tent. Its pretty big so I hope my camp site will accommodate it. There is lots of windows for air flow, the roof has two big sky lights in it which you can't see from the photo, the gray top is actually a canvas you put over the top of it for rain. It is big enough to stand in if you are average height(i'm 5'10).

The only downside I've seen to it is that without the rain cover (gray top in the picture) you have no privacy,you won't be able to change clothes without the gray canvas over top. Other than that its a pretty nice tent. Spacious inside,enough height for an average sized person to stand up in and easy setup.

This is a great deal for an 8 person tent, Wal-Mart was wanting $120 for a 6 person tent so this is definitely a better deal.

Would I recommend this? From my initial setup yes I would.

This is a weird mask to rate because it fits both somewhat large and somewhat small. The mask is larger than my other masks, particularly in the skirt.  The skirt extends up past my hairline which occasionally affects the quality of the seal. It may not be as much of an issue if someone is bald but hair, particularly longer hair, can pose a problem even if combed back. The bottom silicone extends well into the upper lip which could also cause issues if you have a thick mustache.  The field of view is great but the biggest flaw of this mask by far is the nose pocket.  It's way too narrow for me.  I have a wide nose.  this mask pinches it off in a way that causes the adjoining skin underneath to fold, causing a gap which prevents a watertight seal.  If you have a wide nose, I'd STRONGLY suggest testing this at length in a pool (or a tub in a pinch) before trusting it on a trip.  I took another snorkel set with a similarly narrow nose and it leaked like crazy.  Thankfully I took several extra masks and snorkels for just such emergencies. You don't want to get all the way to whatever paradise you plan to snorkel only to discover you have a completely unusable mask.
summary: Large field of view, large skirt, very narrow nose pocket

reviewText:
I have a case for my nice Canon camera that has the same closure system as this case.... it gives you lots of confidence.... and for good reason.  There are three ziplock closures and they all fold down nice and Velcro closed.  This system works very well!  I was glad that this came as a set of two cases.  I use one for my ASUS tablet (shown in pictures) and my boyfriend uses one for his vapor and supplies.  These are a perfect fit for both products.  My ASUS tablet measures 7.5 x 4.25 inches.

I use my tablet on our sailboat for the music and GPS functions so it is important to have a waterproof case that I am very comfortable using around the water.  These cases also have a very sturdy adjustable strap that you can use around your waist or for me, a means to secure the case to the boat.

One case is black and you cannot identify the contents.  The other is a light blue and is see through.  Both function well and keep your expense items safe from water damage.

Savings.... keeping your electronics in working order.  I have gone through several telephones due to water damage and the ocean.  Wasn't willing to take the chance with my tablet.  Now I can take my tablet anywhere.

The watch unit is still functioning well except for the small rubber clasp that broke - that secures the other end of the strap - last month. I just use a black rubber band as a replacement.

The backlighting is not that great but I rarely use it anyway.

Aside from that, I had replaced the battery (CR1632) of the watch unit just once and had yet to replace the battery of the HR sensor unit.

I use the HR sensor unit about 2-3 times a week when I ride my bike and each time, before use, I clean it - the rubberized area under the sensor- with 91% isopropyl alcohol (but any grade would be probably OK) before applying a small dab of Spectra electrode gel.

I rarely get an error message ('transmitter error') on the unit since I used the electrode gel.

The band on the HR sensor unit is very much in good shape - no noticeable sag nor wrinkling on the edges - even after those months, perspiration and all.  Most elasticized bands sag just after several uses but this one is really durable and good quality.

I also clean the watch unit - specially the underside - and well as the straps with a piece of tissue paper dabbed with isopropyl alcohol when my wrist start to itch to remove the buildup of grime.  However, I didn't suffer any allergic reactions to the strap --- just the usual skins marks since I rarely take off the unit off my wrist.

It's truly waterproof (the watch unit) and I had used it in both salt and fresh water environments although the most I have been under water was probably 15 feet.  I had never tried using the HR sensor unit under water if it's also waterproof, though.

For the price I paid - about $74 (tax inclusive), I believe I had gotten my money's worth and that's the bottom line.

It's not fancy and have no snob-appeal,  but it just works.

mid-Aug. 2017 update:

I am really impressed with the quality of the HR monitor band. It had been almost 2 1/2 years of constant use (primarily while riding my bike, 2-3 times a week) and looks like it just had very minimal wear.  No visible sagging nor discoloration in spite of body salt, grime, etc..  I have yet to replace the battery of the HR monitor.

I had replaced the watch strap - also bought off Amazon - with a $8 replacement (although it was narrower -woman's/ladies-version) sometime Nov 2016 and had just replaced the watch battery (CR 1632) this month --just the 2nd time since I purchased the unit in April 2015.

I am really impressed with this Polar FT7 watch which I decided over the first version of the Apple Watch.  Eventually, my decision to go with this Polar was not to have a fitness watch that I will need to charge , at least,  every other day.  The FT7's battery is so easy to replace.

Not only the decision saved me a lot of money, the product is still very, very useful as of this review update!
summary: Simple and functional - Truly got my money's worth since the time I bought it

reviewText:
Some design problems

PROS
1. Easy to assemble and take apart
2. Compact folded size
3. Easy to get out of, even for older people with joint problems. To get up you grab the frame at the rear and push yourself up. The frame is strong enough to take your weight.

CONS
1. The top of the back is angled back so far that your head doesn't come anywhere near it. If you want to rest your head you will need a fairly large pillow, like a large beach towel rolled up. Then you have to find a way to attach it to the chair.
2. The legs sink into the ground terribly. Forget about it in sand. I recommend buying 4 whiffle balls for the feet.
3. I find the back too narrow. It presses uncomfortably on my sides.
4. The price.

My wife couldn't reliably operate my shield due to her lack of grip strength. This device gave her the right amount of purchase to be to chamber rounds and clear malfunctions. Be aware: this device creates a hot spot when carrying iwb. Cheap enough and easy to install/revert back.
summary: Great device to help the grip strength impaired

*Fourteen months later the second helmet I bought is still going strong but the plastic is beginning to get a bit warped (wavy) on the side*.

I've only had this helmet for about two months but today, as I was going to work, it saved my life.
I can't recall what happened but I was going quite fast in the bike lane and suddenly found myself flying off my bike and onto the sidewalk. At the ER I was told I had a concussion- I was experiencing confusion and memory loss - but I didn't have as much as a scrape on my face or head. It held the impact very well and made a big difference between me being here writing this review or being comatose in a hospital bed. My CT scan came back normal and I'm going to order another one of these helmets ASAP.

reviewText: No matter how great your rain cover is, your bag can still get wet. We were in a 2 day torrential rain and anytime you expose your pack by getting contents out it gets wet. Because of the high humidity it never dries. Overall, it was nice to try and keep your gear dry, but sometimes it just isn't possible. So say you wake up to light rain and you need to break camp. You pack up your stuff inside the tent and put on your rain cover and set your pack outside while you breakdown the tent. Do you lay your bag on the muddy ground or stand it upright exposing it on one side to rain and putting your hip belt in the mud? So when you finally have your tent broken down and rolled up/folded, you put that wet sponge where? In your half dry back pack. Now if you are smart, you just throw the tent into a garbage bag to keep the majority of the moisture in the bag and then put it into your pack. Anyway if it is raining more than a mist, this probably isn't going to help much depending on the circumstances. I am a novice and I realize my circumstance is not what yours will be. I am just giving my opinion.
summary: In theory, it is good. In reality, it isn't. Use a garbage bag or trash compactor bag instead.

reviewText: works great

Right up front, consider what you're wanting a First Aid Kit for before buying this pouch. It's very large especially when fully filled out. This pouch would be at home on a backpack, thigh rig, EMT bag, or riding in the back of a vehicle. This is not the pouch to buy if you want to carry a FAK on a belt, plate carrier or chest rig: it's just too large and gets in the way.

That said, it's a great pouch. Very roomy inside with plenty of strapping and loops to hold everything down. There's a fold-out mesh pocket for small things like band-aids, alcohol wipes, and tubes of antibiotic cream. It's compartmentalized quite well allowing for excellent organization, which is critical for a FAK. The outside front of the pouch has a large loop field for various patches (morale, name tape, blood type, drug allergy, etc.) and 3 rows of MOLLE webbing for attaching additional pouches. I don't think i'd suggest it though: the pouch is retained to the rip-away panel by the large velcro field on the back, as well as a nylon strap with a fastex buckle out front. If you put additional pouches on the front, the strap may not be long enough to be used. Not good if the pouch gets snagged and ripped off the velcro field. At most, I'd use the front MOLLE webbing to hold  things like pens, chem-lights and similar small things.

Now a negative. The back of the rip-away panel has MOLLE webbing every other row, rather than every row. I'm a bit disappointed by this because right now I'm hanging this off a belt and it moves around way too much. If it had MOLLE every row I could get it down tight like the Pistol Mag pouch. But, as I said, it's not meant for belt use. On a pack or bag with a large MOLLE field, this pouch can be anchored down solidly, which is important because the velcro holds the pouch to the panel tightly, requiring a good bit of force to pull off.

Overall it's a good pouch, but think about what you need before you buy.

The one I received is their newer version. On this one, the back of the rip-away panel has the threading strips stitched to the panel: the old version has fully removable straps. If one or the other is important to you, consider buying somewhere when you can see the product beforehand. Otherwise, it doesn't really matter.

It's typical Condor quality. The stitching is solid, the nylon is fairly heavy and stiff, and velcro good and grippy. I expect it to last a good long time with moderate use. It's a quality product at a reasonable price.
summary: Think before buying: it could be too big.

reviewText:
Portable, stainless steel, ease of use and design...... are the pillars for this stove.

Portable: -No better way to put it.
  -How many other stoves can you disassemble and put in your - Pant pocket/bag/backpack/jacket/day hike bag/cooler/backpacking backpack? It comes with a case to keep the soot from coming into contact with yourself/items in bag.
  -Folds flat as promised, incredibly thin (so much so, it took me back holding it, and I thought to myself "and you can really cook with this thing?").
  -Did I mention you don't need to pack your fuel! Just grab sticks/grass/pine cones as you walk on your hike/trail/in your yard. So all you're paying for is the stove, baring matches/fire strike/other lighting method cost.

Stainless steel: -Talk about awesome option, for those of us that live in areas where it rains. This model (I've not tried out the titanium) feels stout and can hold good weight (I don't own a Dutch oven, yet, but it could handle it).
  -DON'T BE AFRAID! The stove looks nice when you first get it, but after use, it will change to rainbow and soot colors (which just means you're using it!). Use baking soda and vinegar to get majority of soot off.
Ease of use: -Ever tied your shoes? Put a puzzle together? No different with this stove!
  -Fits together nicely and tightly. Make sure to put in good flammable tinder to get hot, then start putting in thin sticks through the opening in the front, working up to larger diameter sticks (essentially when you have enough coals to light/sustain larger pieces of wood.) If you need a good tutorial, go onto U-tube and the founder has a good line of videos to get you set.

Design: -This caught my eye right away. The stove is like a mini ziggurat of Mesopotamia (pyramid with flat top). This accounts for the stability, as opposed to competitors who use a box/rectangle structure. This stove does not want to topple over!

***As others have said, make sure to take OFF the clear plastic shipping covers on each panel (it keeps the panels looking pretty prior to using the stove), when you first get it, or you'll be burning plastic (and breathing in plastic fumes :( ).***

I've been using this stove, and it not only cooks well (and smokeless, if you do it right) but it radiates heat because of it's steel make (I've heard titanium heats up fast, but also cools fast too, but to be fair, I have not used one yet.).

CAN'T SAY ENOUGH ABOUT THIS STOVE!
I can see it lasting the lifetime guarantee the maker gives it!

I of course bought this for camping, but I bought a lot of new gear recently, and I couldn't help but go into the backyard for a little test of my new: axe sharpener, fire starter, and this little guy, with the solo stove pot that it fits inside.

It works great! I boiled water, and cooked a bag of ramen noodle soup in it, afterwards I cooked a single egg. I was skeptical on how long the fire could possibly last, you do get a little opening to feed more stuff in, but I did not want to have to baby the fire the entire time when I should be focusing on making my meal taste good. If you load it with good wood, it will easily sit and cook without need of too much intervention, stuff like bark pinecones and leaves were also effective, however those you DO have to constantly feed, because they just burn too fast.

I would indeed recommend this product to any camper, but there is certainly one very big downside, it's price....at about 90 USD for the pot and this stove combo, I would label that as "insanely expensive" for what you are actually getting. That being said it is very sturdy, and I have no worries of damaging it from lugging it around in my camping/hiking bag.

reviewText:
This is my everyday watch.  It is good looking, well-made (for the price) and durable thus far. Only con is that it seems to gain couple seconds a day, therefore, at the end of the month, it is about minute or two fast -  I suppose it's better than  being slow but this is expected from a non-quartz movement type of watches that use unadjusted automatic movement.  It's a trade-off for not having the need to replace the battery every few years.  If you are like me and like to wear different watches for different occasions, auto-movement watches can be a pain unless you invest in auto-winder or two.

I disagree with some people; I think Invicta watches in general (I have several Invictas) have decent bands that are nicely finished and have sufficient heft to them. Compared to comparable Seiko 5 automatic watches, Seikos have cheap, light weight, rough feel to them, although the Seiko 5 are also a good choice for a daily beater - their bands tend to give out long before their auto-movements do. These Pro Diver series that ape Rolex/Omega design are the ones that put Invicta on the map in the watch world.

Although the style is easy to copy, customer service apparently is not as noted by many user here and other watch forums. But then, if I get several years of trouble-free use out them, I'm happy. If you want the legendary service, you gonna have to pony up for a real thing (Rolex) through its authorized dealer.

Comparing this knife to my two other Spydercos--an Endura with ATS-55 steel from circa 1998 and one with H1 steel from 2014.

Both of those knives are great in their own right.  They're lightweight, compact, easy to operate, and slow to dull.  The PM2 takes everything that's great about them and bumps it up one notch.  It's razor sharp out of the box, has smoother action that requires less effort, and is just as light while also being more robust in the hand.  Plus the hole is bigger and easier to use, even with gloves on.  It's debatable whether those improvements are worth a price that's nearly double, but make no mistake--this is one exceptional folder!

The *only* thing that makes the Enduras better for EDC is that they're thinner.
summary: The Gold Standard for EDC Folders

reviewText:
I hate to give these goggles a poor review, as I wanted to love them. My first impression was that they were vividly clear and comfortable. They have a clip in the back which I did not find necessary for me, but it was not bothersome either - even though I have longer hair and wear it in a ponytail under my swim cap.
In the pool when I put them on I noticed the discomfort of the nose piece immediately, but with a slight adjustment improved this, though it was still noticeable. The clarity of the lenses above the water was honestly magnificent. However when I went under the water they were terribly blurry - not fog, blur. So blurry I could not even complete one lap because it was throwing off my equilibrium and causing motion sickness. I swim almost daily and have never experienced this sensation with any other goggles. Apparently I am not the only person who has experienced this.

Quite literally! The route back home entails passing through a few blocks that are pretty lacking in overhead lighting, as well as sidewalks, for that matter. That means being out on the road with oncoming traffic, no stop signs, and no lights. And while I don't have a bike like most of the folks buying this, I DO have a wheelchair, and suffer the same problem that they do with the poor visibility.

So, I picked up a roll of the lime color, thinking it'd come close to matching my bright green spokes. For one, the color is completely off: it's more of a dull yellow than the bright green glow you see in the photo. And even then, that wouldn't be that bad, if it actually increased my nighttime visibility. But nope, it doesn't even do that: the tape I received was no more reflective than the stickers you get from the DMV to put on your license plates. In other words, barely reflective at all. At first I thought this was just because it needed direct light shone on it, but having experimented with both a flashlight at various angles, and out in the wild with oncoming cars, I can fairly confidently say that I'm not going to be a shining star anytime soon.

Purchased a Truglo red dot sight as a bit of an impulse buy at a local shop; did not account for the front A2 sight and after initial mounting realized this riser would be required. Worked perfectly to align red dot with Magpul flip-up rear, fixed A2 front sights.

I had this on my wishlist for awhile and my wife ordered it for me as a "for no reason" surprise. She's the best!

I got the 4 inch version as the 6 incher would run afoul of my state's max blade length. As always make sure you are familiar with your local laws.

The knife arrived sharp enough to shave the hair off the back of my hand. Construction appears to be first rate. I'm not a huge fan of liner locks but that is just a personal preference. This knife locks up nice and tight and there are no worries about it collapsing on your fingers. I do not find it hard to disengage the lock to fold it, nor is it too easy where one would fear an unintentional disengagement.

Using the thumb stud the blade swings out fairly smoothly, though it is initially a bit stiff. Perhaps this will ease up over time but in any case it isn't oppressive. On the top and bottom of the base of the blade are two small serrated finger guards. The top one remains fully exposed when the knife is closed, the purpose of which is to catch on your pants as you draw the knife from your pocket to open the knife for you. I've found that unless I consciously try to do this it doesn't work, and even why I try to it is hit or miss. There is nothing wrong with this feature per se, but do not buy this knife specifically for this. Also, don't rely on it to speed up the time it takes to get your knife into action in an emergency. You are much better off practicing opening the knife manually...and won't wear holes in your jeans from the constant friction.

In all this is a very nice defensive knife. It isn't a jack of all trades like many pocketknives tend to be...it was deigned purely as a defensive weapon. If this is what you need and enjoy the elegant lines and feel of a butterfly style knife but can't have/don't want one of those than this Cold Steel should be on your short list.

reviewText:
I have had this knife for over a month and have gone backpacking a few times with her on my belt. It's a very attractive knife with a wonderful balance which just begs to be thrown. Now I'm no knife thrower but given the weight and balance I thought it would best be for me to throw the knife like a "missile", just overhead like a baseball and then release/and point at the target(not end over end she just flys straight). Voila!  She travels well and many a dead tree suffered a fatal blow with the 1620 going deep into the wood. I felt like John Wayne on "The Big Trail". Wow. Of course I often did not get it quite right and "bang" the knife bounced off the wood (at times directly back at me, be careful!) and in short order the pins (which are not brass, only brass covers) came off as well as the small brass covers, Old Timer Name tag and fracture of plastic handle.  This didn't stop me, I just taped the knife up with first aid tape and when back home I replaced the pins with 5/16x3/4" tension pins, epoxyed the thing together, and then wrapped electrical tape on the handle. She's pretty bomb proof now and if you are going to throw this knife you should just start by disassemblying the handle and epoxy gluing the entire thing. I used this knife in the backcountry in cutting off a root under my tent; nice thick blade for ugly work such at that. Very nice and comfortable shief as well; rides well on the belt.

The key to understanding this knife is it's under $20!!  What a value, if you modify as I have outlined you'll love the thing and you too can pretend to be The Duke on The Big Trail (great movie by the way).

I've used a double walled "wood gas" stove for a few years now.  I've made them myself, and use both the original Solo and Solo Titan.  I love this method of camp cooking for a few reasons, but I'll get into that in a moment.  First, to concentrate on the product at hand.

The stove comes in a nylon bag, nested in the pot, which also has a nylon bag.  Good packaging, as this keeps debris out of your pot.  For a size reference, a quart paint can is the same diameter as the stove and roughly the same height with the pot stand in its packed state.

The pot is a stainless steel pitcher with folding wire handles and graduated volume markings.  It works well on the Solo or any other small stove, like a Svea123.  The pot won't quite nest the Svea, to my disappointment, but it wasn't made to, so that isn't Solo's fault.

Using a wood gas stove has a bit of a learning curve.  You are making a tiny campfire in there and some care has to be taken to do it properly, so you can have enough fire to cook on.  Wax/Vaseline soaked cotton balls or those generic fire sticks you can get at walmart are the firestarters I use most often, and once burning its an easy thing to maintain a little fire in a small space, as long as you choose the proper fuel.  I'd suggest doing a couple of practice burns in the back yard before the first time out in the field, so you can learn the ins and outs of the stove.

Why a natural fuel stove in the first place though, isn't it easier to just screw on a gas bottle and boil away?  Well, yes and no.

Liquid or gas fueled stoves need...fuel.  Which is stored in heavy containers, and will eventually run out.  For a survival tool, this is a huge problem.  Even stoves like my MSR Dragonfly, which will burn pretty much anything petrol based, will eventually fail because a small part will wear out, the pump on the fuel bottle will snap, an O-ring will go bad, etc.  Spares take up more space and weight in your pack.  If you are bugging out, you want a stove that weighs very little and doesn't need you to carry its fuel.

The beauty of the Solo amongst natural fuel stoves is its efficient burn, due to its secondary combustion.  You can find enough fallen twigs to boil water in mere moments.  The stove and pot together weigh less than my Svea123 considerably.  It is an excellent solution for lightweight backpackers and survivalists both.

For car camping I would suggest the Solo Titan.  It burns longer and can support cookwear for several.  The original Solo is a single person tool.

There are many reviews of this stove and other natural fuel and wood gas stoves out there, so new ground isn't being broken by mine.  The issue to consider is not "should I get a Solo Stove, is it any good?"  Yes, it is excellent at what it does.  The issue is "Do I want a natural fuel stove?" I find the advantages of natural fuel to outweigh the fact that they take a bit more tending during a boil, and are a bit messier than a gas stove.  Light weight, quality construction, versatility, compactness.  These are the reasons I backpack AND car camp with Solo stoves, big and small.

Hope this was helpful to you, check out TheGearWhores on Facebook/Twitter and our website for more, and keep camping!
summary: TheGearWhores.com Review of the Solo Stove and Solo 900 Pot:

reviewText:
These are very similar to the old GI camo that came in the metal tubes. As such, the same uses/methods apply.
Pro Tips: You'll find that it is easier to apply the camo with a finger instead of dragging the grease paint over your face. Rubbing the stick with your finger will warm it up enough to apply.
If it is really cold, you can run a lighter flame near it to soften it up. If that doesn't work, you should have some sort of face cover on anyway.
Correct method for camo pattern: light colors on the nose, forehead, cheekbones, chin; darker colors elsewhere. There is a reason for this, to avoid the Shiny Effect.

UPDATE : Having used this camo a couple of times in the past month, I have to report that it doesn't work well, in that it doesn't stay on the face long.  At all.
summary: Looks Much Like the Old GI Tubes

Here's a review from someone that DOESN'T have anything to do with carrying kids; in today's $4.00 per gallon gas, I decided I needed a human-powered cargo unit to bring to the grocery store, the mall or wherever else in order to bring stuff home without making yet another car trip. This trailer is an almost-perfect solution! The construction is VERY sturdy, it has massive carrying capacity (6 full grocery bags and handles the weight easily), aluminum frame makes it lightweight, AND best of all the 16" front wheel which makes rolling it for distance a breeze - that wheel is definitely this unit's selling point as opposed to the 'shopping cart' front wheels you see on others. The only slight drawbacks are the somewhat difficult setup to hook it up to a bike, and I'd like it to have a solid bottom instead of nylon to make it sturdier for cargo. But it WAS designed to haul kids, and putting a bottom on was a pretty easy thing for me to do, so no big deal. All in all, the price for a unit like this makes it a great deal (I do have to mention I bought it a couple of weeks ago when the price was $45 cheaper! Lucky me!) so if you're looking for a cargo trailer like me, I don't think you can go wrong with this one.

reviewText:
I got mine from the Toaks website (only place to get the 137mm fry pan) because I needed to bump total price above $50 for free shipping. No worries, the prices are the same as Amazon. Besides, I wanted one for the new kit.
It nests comfortably in my Toaks 1300ml pot with bail. I like the longer handles also. Since I always carry leather gloves when backpacking, insulation isn't a problem. When I nest the Toaks 375ml cup inside in it's stuff sack, the top floats a little. But no worries, the stuff sack still covers everything nicely enough. I keep the lid on the bottom.
My new Toaks kit consists of the 1300ml pot with bail, the 700ml pot, the 375ml cup, and the frypan riding on the bottom of the bigger pot. I put a Trangia in the cup wrapped in a microfiber wash rag, and put a piece of Scotch Brite in between the frypan and pot bottom.
The whole kit takes up less space than my Toaks 1.6l combo by a good bit.  Outside dimensions are about 5.5"D x 4"H for the smaller kit vs. 5.75"D x 6"H. That's because the frying pan for the smaller kit nests on the pot, creating much less headspace.
Can't wait for fall to try it on a trip. Will cook with it several times before then, but I can see no reason that it shouldn't work as well as my older Toaks gear.
summary: Fits nicely in my new Toaks kit

I bought this just to have a lighter bow for friends who come over and want to try shooting arrows but never have before. This is a great beginners bow. I would suggest using arrows with real feathers, nothing plastic, because though it has an ambidextrous riser with an arrow rest I still cut my hand as the feathers (not vanes, that probably would have been worse of a cut) shot across my hand. Perhaps one should also wear a glove and hold the riser a bit low. There are little bumps on the riser for a better grip; when I cut my hand I had my index finger above the first bump, which put the arrow rest pretty much flush with the top of my hand. Putting your index finger between the two bumps will get the top of your hand out of the way, though with my adult male hands being on the bigger side of average my pinky slips a little off the bottom because this bow is designed for young beginners. I would also suggest replacing the string; the one it comes with seems to be a type of paracord and a bit too thin for my arrows nocks to grip. There are also several other reviews saying the string broke at the brass connection points after very few shots, one even said it happened on the very first shot.
summary: Great beginners bow. Use real feathers, nothing plastic, and replace the string.

reviewText: Very substantial, fits the Mini 14 like a glove.  I own a stainless Mini 14 Ranch Rifle and have never been happy with the wood stock.  Given the current environment, decided against anything "assault rifle" looking.  Glad I went witht he Hogue.  Installation was a piece of cake.  This stock feels very solid, comfortable to grip. reviewText:
I have had this knife for a few years now. I REALLY liked the idea of a SOG knife that was affordable as I trust the name.

I should say that while this knife is very impressive and the steel really takes an edge and is durable I stopped using this knife almost completely and its sitting in a box in the storage room.  the saw back is embarrassingly gimmicky. I thought I would just not use it but it interferes with the practical use of the knife. it has snagged on my clothing <minor gripe but when it puts holes in clothes its just a bummer> and prevents me from being able to baton logs as it chews up the log or other implement I am striking the blade with.

I find it really too small to use as a machete and too large to use as a knife. actually I have a few machetes that I use constantly <imacasa for 15 bucks> and a regular sized pocket knife. <which someone should probably always carry anyway... be prepared>

Don't let my words here talk you out of buying this knife if you want it.  its a good knife but the way I see it its a solution looking for a problem. I much prefer a simple machete that will do any job this knife will do and probably do it better.  I guess it just depends on what you are looking for in a knife. I find it mostly useless for what I do.  you may get it  and find it invaluable for your system.  for me there are better choices to be had but I am not willing to get rid of this knife because one day it may prove its self useful somehow.
summary: It's A Nice Knife But A Plain Machete Is More Useful

I was very impressed this this bottle from the moment I took it out of the packaging!  The first thing that I noticed was the beautiful steel body of the shaker.  This aspect ensures that this is a product that can be used over a lifetime.  It is durable and prohibits absorption so you won't have to worry about how you will get that funky smell out!  The lid snaps closed very securely so there is no worry about your shakes or other liquids leaking or spilling from a lid that isn't secure.  The entire lid itself screws on and off easily.  There are convenient measurements on the side of the shaker and a beautiful etched logo on the front.  The bottom portion screws off to reveal a multipurpose storage compartment!  Good for protein powders, snacks or to use as a mini serving cup/bowl for the liquid content.  I was surprised to find a wire ball inside of the shaker that is to be used when shaking your drink to ensure the powder breaks up well and is dispersed throughout the drink, making sure to make a perfect shake every time!  This is a high quality product and I would recommend it!  I must disclose that I received this product free of charge to review and share my honest and unbiased opinion.  The opinions formed and expressed about this product are 100% my own and have not in any way been influenced.
summary: The last shaker you will need to buy!

reviewText: I am a 5'9" blonde white male (Finnish) with distinctly Scandinavian features. I am of medium build and my face is a medium size. These sunglasses are a great fit for my face. I have previously purchased the excellent Pepper's Men's Half Life Sport Polarized Sunglasses which were of superb quality but were a bit too large on my face. I still wore them until I lost them. The Suncloud Optics Hook sunglasses are of equal quality as far as I can tell, but I really like the shape. They look great on my face and they are the perfect size: nice and snug but not too tight. Important Note: The Gray Backpaint means that the frames are a translucent black/gray color, and the inside is yellow. This is EXACTLY as pictured!!! In the light the sunglasses are translucent through to the yellow, and this males them look slightly green. This isn't a problem for me but if you want black sunglasses, then get the BLACK version (which I would probably prefer but whatever, not worth exchanging). Oh, and of course, they do a great job on blocking the sun, and the lenses are perfectly consistent. (What I see is slightly shifted up from my normal vision but I have never had a pair of glasses that didn't change something). Most important to me is that they do not have any power/magnification and don't give me a headache.

After years of blowing at camp fires through pursed lips and getting a face and eyes and lungs full of smoke, I saw a product demonstrated on a Bush Craft video.  It was only available in Europe...  Then I found this on Amazon.  It is stainless steel so it is not light weight for its (small) size.  Its value is in its function and in its collapsiblity.  From a collapsed state of just under 4 inches, it extends to 19 inches,  The larger (.5 inches, diameter) end is placed in the mouth and the narrow end concentrates  oxygenated air from your lungs to a focused stream at the narrow end. Once an initial spark or flame has begun to produce an ember, combustion can be sped up by directing more air precisely at the ember.  That sure beats watching helplessly while the initial spark fails to catch and fades to nothing.  On a dry day with dry, finely processed wood, this might not be needed...but on a cold, damp day with wood that is a bit damp, this makes all the difference between fire and failure.  At first, this device will be stiff to open and close but a little lubricant will help.  Opened up, the rod is sturdy and should last for a good many fires.
summary: One Difference Bewteen Fire and Failure

reviewText:
I bought this for my Ruger GP100 with 4" barrel. The fit is good and it's actually pretty comfortable to wear. However, the plastic construction is a bit stiff and I'm not confident the adjustable screw mechanism will stand the test of time. I had to back the adjustment screw out a bit in order to make the pistol easier to draw from the holster. However, there is a rubber washer on the scew that is no longer in contact with anything........so I suspect that the adjustment screw will start to creep open with continued use.
I don't plan to holster this pistol very often, so for my purposes (and for the low price) the holster is OK for me. However if I ever decide to start carrying this pistol on a frequent basis, I'd definitely look for something a bit better (and probably more expensive). For the money, it's a pretty good product though. I'd give it 3.75 stars if I could.
Fits perfectly

I have to say that I am quite impressed with the talon grips. They give a much more comfortable grip (especially the very aggressive FNX-45 stippling). They give better grip dry or wet.

Make sure to follow the instructions when installing (make sure to clean VERY well with the included alcohol swab). Take your time applying the grip and that there are no air bubbles. Then use a heat gun to secure it and all is well. If you have a temp controlled heat gun I would use 250-300 as it worked the best.

After getting this one I have also purchased ones for my PPQ, VP9, FNX-9 (Friends gun), and for my AR.
summary: They give a much more comfortable grip (especially the very aggressive FNX-45 stippling)

I never thought I would have a need to send for 3 pound dumbbells. And then I had a shoulder injury that required physical therapy for several months. I bought this basket for my bicycle about a year ago. I give it three stars because I think it's an okay product, but not great. I have used it lightly on a commuter bike to hold my bacpack on a two mile ride to and from work. I'd say I've ridden to work and back maybe 50 times, so the basket has seen maybe 250 miles of use. All of these miles are on pavement. The worst abuse it has seen is going off a curb at low speed every once in a while. I mention the details of my commute because I think it may give some perspective when considering con #2 below.

Pros:
-It is neat that the basket is removable. I never use it, but it's good to have the option. This is really what sold me on the basket in the first place.
-The basket stays firmly attached to the basket hardware when on the bike. No troubles there.

Cons:
-The bottom of the hardware rests on the front of handlebar post where it exits the frame. This has a tendency to sway away from the bike at times. I'm not sure if it is just my bike, but I solved the problem with a zip tie and a smile.
-One of the two bottom hooks on the hardware holding the basket broke off about a month ago. The good news here is that it is still held firmly enough for my comfort by the remaining three attachment points (two top and now one bottom hook). It has a little more play in it, but nothing that would cause the contents to go tumbling out.

I give it three stars for mediocre design and modest durability.

reviewText:
Very satisfied with these playing cards, and will be using for my regular poker decks.  They arrived in good condition, including the plastic box.

Pros:
* Good feel for plastic cards, they shuffle well and are NOT overly slick as compared to some cheaper brands.
* Excellent printing on both back and display sides of cards.  Pattern on back is especially excellent and uniform.
* Very durable!!  I subjected the enclosed KEM card which is of equivalent thickness and construction to test abuse.  Will NOT tear, did not crease with anything except actually folding in half.  Cleans up well with no apparent loss of printing colour or intensity or smearing including testing with cola and 151 proof rum, even dried simple syrup & grenadine syrup washed off nicely with moderately hot water and dish soap.
* Very flat and uniform.  No warping or torsional twisting after repeated shuffling.

CON
* The STUPID looking nose picking fat joker is a MAJOR drawback.  It is so annoying in appearance that I down rated to 4 Stars just because of it!  For those who play silly new-age yuppie poker such as Texas hold'em and Omaha this would not be a problem so you folks can consider this a FIVE STAR review, but for traditionalists like me who play only 5 & 7 card stud and 5 card draw and with the standard ONE joker for aces, straights and flushes, this thing is an unnecessary annoyance.  Same problem for other single deck games such as 7 & 10 pt Pitch and Euchre which use one or more joker The joker's are easily differentiated however so you can have high and low joker.  You listening KEM?

reviewText: As a soldier, avid outdoorsman and firearms instructor, I have encountered many packs and range bags.  My initial impressions of this one are that it is a very good idea and a remarkable bargain for such quality at under $70.  Upon receiving it, I expended an entire aerosol can of waterproofing on its inside and outside.  It is tightly and strongly made, and there are many nooks and crannies.  The product video will help some purchasers assemble it.  True, it is not an ideal backpack, but it can certainly be carried short distances.  More importantly, it is a great disguise.  I live in a high rise situated in a university town where backpacks are ubiquitous and firearms are not universally loved. I wish I had ordered the green one. Even in brown, it attracts no attention in elevators, hallways, parking lots, etc.  It needs, as other reviewers mention, external Molle attachment strips, and all of the velcro should to be about twice as wide.  The initial design appears to originate with competitive shooters - thus the many magazine loops, stapler pouch, etc., that are useful for those who want to score points in shooting games.  Of the five external pockets, three are the same small size, just right for competitors' magazines, but impractical for much else. Two of these could usefully  be replaced with a single, general-purpose pocket.  Happily, more serious shooters with practical goals will find that the pack's fundamental design allows much customization.  To accommodate the procedures of an indoor range where I often teach, I have added an external earmuff container and a tube to contain rolled targets of the appropriate size.  If the pack holds up under hard use, I'll probably buy another in green and set it up for outdoor ranges.  By then, this company or a competitor may offer a similar pack with more adaptable features..  As it is, even with a few shortcomings, this is a solid piece of gear at a very favorable price.

reviewText:
For a Bersa Thunder .380 this holster can seem a bit on the large side, but I actually like it that way. The pistol is kept very snug and this way all the moving parts are kept out of reach of curious fingers.
It is obvious that this is a generic holster, that is made like "one size fits all", and the Velcro straps makes it adjustable. The thumb release doesn't work as easily as on a leather holster, because the nylon has too much flex it it, but as described above, this keeps it very secure when latched.

A hint for adjusting the Velcro side straps:
Have a broad bladed butter knife, or any flat and wide material to put between the loops and the hooks of the Velcro. If you don't, then you aren't adjusting anything, because it keeps gripping, and you can't slide the straps up or down.

For someone who just want a comfy holster to occasionally strap on a belt, or just something to store or transport your pistol in, this is one of the cheapest and best solutions out there.
Highly recommended!

Considering the numerous reviews stating the snugpak bergen usually arrives poorly stitched, I expected To do some minor repairing when it arrived. True to expectations, it did indeed arrive in a sorry state. I have included photos. 1) The cinch bag at the top was completely unsewn and left with large fraying edges by a span of about 7 inches. 2) one of the zipper stops was completely missing and I had to rig thread there to render it useable. 3) one strap was sewn very shoddy.
Despite this, I love the Bergen and would buy more. It is an excellent value for the money and the utility.
* However I see one area that is an inherent design flaw built into the Bergen itself. The zippers which hold the removable side bags seal upward instead of downward. Thus the weight of a full side bag, as well as gravity and torc  will be forever trying to pull that zipper down making that area a permanent  potential weakness. The zippers don't self lock either.

It's comfortable even when full and does not interfere with range of motion.
