Let's get the big controversy out of the way first: The trailer as a whole is great but as others have reported the tires that come with it are junk. But it's so inexpensive - I paid a few pennies more than eighty-four dollars here on Amazon - I didn't hold the tires against it. Since I read the reviews before making my purchase, I expected the tires to be low quality Chinese junk. I don't know if the tubes are equally crappy because I haven't yet needed to remove the tires to look at the tubes. I haven't had any trouble with them yet but if I have flats or blowouts I've got the right size tubes in my spare parts box already since the front wheel of my recumbent uses the same size tubes (16"/305 x 1.75"). If I ever take the trailer any real distance I'll bring spare tubes for it just as I bring spare tubes for my bike on such a trip. And while the tires are junk they aren't going to be holding the weight of an adult, only a max of 70lbs and usually a lot less, so I don't think they'll be a problem. If the tires do prove to be a problem there are a bunch of 16"/305 tires in my local bike shop and here on Amazon, some relatively inexpensive but plenty good enough (such as Kenda Kwests) and others a bit more expensive but really, really good (such as Schwalbe Big Apples or Marathon GGs). For now I'll use the included tires and tubes until they wear out or cause a problem; I am prepared for but don't expect a problem and they should last a year or more before needing replacement.

I am moving along an asymptote toward a nearly car-free lifestyle. I do most of my local travel, errands, and visiting using a bike; mostly my Sun EZ-1 Lite recumbent although I also have an early-90s Schwinn hybrid and a little Dahon folder. The one thing I found myself still wanting a car for is to do shopping trips that involve bulk items such as paper towels, larger potted plants, etc. The solution to this is a cargo trailer. There are lots available and I did my research, eventually settling on the Burley Travoy. Unfortunately, there is no good way to get the Travoy's hitch to work with my EZ-1 because it has no seat tube and the rack is too low to the ground; too bad because I really liked the ability to use the Travoy cargo trailer as a handcart. After spending over a month trying to come up with inventive ways to get the Travoy hitched to my EZ-1, I went back to research mode and narrowed my choices down to the Burley Nomad and the Allen Sports ACT200 Explorer. The Nomad is a very high-quality trailer from a company well-known for its high-quality products, with more interior cargo space and a higher weight capacity than the Explorer. The Nomad is also lighter because it has an aluminum frame vs the Explorer's steel frame and a much better-designed hitch using an elastomer vs the Explorer's universal joint. But the Explorer had two things going for it that I liked a lot: It could be quickly converted to a convenient handcart mode and it was way, way, WAY less expensive than the Nomad. Even at the highest prices I saw for the Explorer (around one-hundred twenty five) and the lowest I saw for the Nomad (around two-hundred thirty) there was a one-hundred dollar difference - you can pretty much buy two or three Explorers for the price of one Nomad. Even if the reviews claiming that the Explorer's included tires and tubes were so bad they would need to be immediately replaced were true, the Explorer remained a bargain. So I decided to at least give the Explorer a try since the price was so appealing and it had that handcart mode.

The Explorer cargo trailer comes almost fully assembled in its box. Just lift it out of the box, unzip the zipper, pull the wheels out of the cargo compartment, pop the wheels on, then attach the hitch arm to the trailer. This takes barely longer to do than it does to read about. After that, attach the hitch plate to your bike's rear axle. I purchased two extra hitch plates directly from Allen Sports (they're not available here on Amazon) in order to have a hitch plate on all three of my bikes. This is also trivially easy to do, although it's possible with a quick-release rear hub that you'll find that the hitch plate is thick enough so that the skewer won't be long enough with the hitch plate attached. If that's the case, go to your local bike shop or look around here on Amazon or another online store for a longer skewer; they're not expensive and they're easy to find. The hitch plate fit fine on my Schwinn (quick-release skewer) and Dahon (nutted axle) but not on my EZ-1 (quick-release skewer) but I had a longer skewer for the EZ-1 sitting in my spare parts box so that didn't slow me down.

I did experience a moment of confusion when attaching the wheels. At first, I thought that the wheel axles were supposed to go under the trailer bed, partially supporting the trailer bed. But the first time I put a load into the trailer bed, the trailer bed sagged down and the axles poked into the sides of the trailer. I communicated via email with Allen Sports and they told me that the axles are SUPPOSED to poke into the sides of the trailer and in fact the cargo compartment is reinforced in that area to prevent damage. This is not apparent in any of the pictures or videos I saw before my purchase but you'll see the reinforced patches right away as you pull the trailer out of its box; I thought they were just decorative at first.

Before putting the wheels on, pressurize them. The tires on the wheels are rated for 30-60PSI but there is a stick-on label on the wheels that says "30 PSI MAX" so pump them to 30PSI, no higher. If you don't have a pump with a pressure gauge, get one. If you over pressurize and the crappy tubes pop the crappy tires off the rims or the crappy tubes =POP= that's probably your fault, not the fault of Allen Sports or Amazon. By the way, the wheels are mostly plastic but they seem to be perfectly round and straight; weird if you're used to "normal" bike wheels with separate hub, spokes, and rim but they seem to work fine and certainly there should be no need for truing these wheels or using rim tape to protect the inner tube from the nonexistent spokes.

The universal joint at the end of the hitch arm which attaches to the hitch plate on the bike works fine. It's a good inexpensive way to allow the bike to move in relation to the trailer without damaging the hitch arm, trailer, or bike. The trailer can flip over without affecting your bike (other than the drag if you keep riding, of course), or you can lay your bike down on the ground without affecting the trailer. An elastomer would be better as a universal joint can get stiff or even experience damage if movement occurs around more than one axis simultaneously; but of course the universal joint is much less expensive and that's what you get with the Explorer: An inexpensive solution that works.

I don't notice the empty trailer behind my bike at all, except for the noise of it bouncing around on the potholes. The first couple of times I used it on smooth roads I had to keep looking back to be sure it was still there; when empty, it doesn't affect the handling of the bike at all and even though it's 20lbs empty I didn't notice it even on uphills. Loaded with 60lbs of soil from the garden store, sure, I noticed it going uphill but on the flats or downhills it was like it wasn't there except when starting or stopping. Of course it's harder to ride uphill pulling more weight and it takes a little more effort to accelerate and you have to give yourself more room to brake to a stop from a high speed. Physics, DUH! The trailer itself, however, rides better with a load than without because at 20lbs empty it bounces around on rough road quite a bit but even a modest load, another 20lbs or so, helps to keep it from bouncing around. Low-pressure tires designed for shock absorption, such as the Schwalbe Big Apple, would probably reduce the bouncing while unloaded.

The zippered compartment, when zipped closed, is 26" long/19" wide/7" high which looks and functions larger than it sounds. It's good for small items and pizzas. For most shopping, the zippered compartment works nicely and holds quite a bit of stuff, more than the two baskets on my Schwinn combined. It's also good for keeping things inside clean (freshly washed laundry, for example) and dry (the cargo compartment isn't waterproof but if you get caught in a sprinkle for a short time it's better than nothing). The cargo compartment also has an interior divider that can be zipped up or folded flat, leaving a slightly larger space in the rear and a slightly smaller space in the front. It's hard to get stuff into or out of the rear space when the divider is zipped up because the top cover gets in the way. It might be useful for people carrying only a few items, or if you want to be able to reach some items easily while keeping other stuff covered. But I haven't used the divider yet, I just keep it unzipped and folded flat, leaving one large space in the cargo compartment. I often find myself unzipping the top, laying it mostly flat on the trailer bed, and then putting bulky items on top of that. The interior side panels have three tie-down ring anchors each and I keep three long bungies and a cargo net to use with them; the cargo net for multiple smaller items and the bungies for big items like a box I have to bring to the post office.

One of the things I like most about the Explorer is handcart mode. To go from trailer mode to handcart mode, just detach the hitch arm from your bike, unscrew a big black knob on the trailer, swivel the hitch arm from horizontal to vertical, then screw down that big black knob to tighten the hitch arm in that position. It's great for shopping because you  fill it up as you walk around the store, unload it at checkout, then load it back up again after paying with no need to waste plastic or paper bags. No need to compete with other shoppers for a cart because you have your own and no worries that you're buying too much stuff to bring home in a single trip. It's not quite as useful or convenient to use this way as a Travoy, but at 1/2-1/3 the price of a Travoy the Explorer is plenty good enough.

To repeat the point of the first paragraph of this review: Please note that my 5-star rating is not a comment on the quality of the tires and tubes. I've seen the tires, I agree with other reviews that they are crap. I haven't seen the tubes (because they're inside the tires and I haven't yet needed to remove the tires) yet I have no doubt that they're crap, too. But I haven't had issues with them and I have spare tubes on hand if needed, and replacement tires are easy to get if and when needed. The welds on the steel parts as well as all the other bits of the trailer don't have the quality one would get from Burley but everything is functional and strong. Given the price, this trailer is an excellent value. You can pay more (a LOT more) and get better quality. You can't pay less; I don't think there is even a half-decent cargo trailer made by anyone available for a lower price. The handcart mode is invaluable for me and the standard axle hitch attachment makes it usable with any bike, including my EZ-1. I would recommend it for anyone looking for a bargain cargo trailer and for whom the 70lb weight capacity is sufficient.

edit 2015-01-17: I've been using the trailer frequently for a couple of months now and I remain very pleased with it. However, note my comment above about the universal joint. Last night while bringing home pizza for the family, the joint locked up and the trailer flipped onto its side while I was making a turn. I had to disconnect the hitch and "work it" with my hands to loosen it up, after which I reattached it and completed the ride home without incident. I have a feeling this will happen every now and then. Infrequently, but it will happen. Universal joints usually work fine, but they can lock up as mine did last night. While I'm not deducting a star, it would be better if Allen Sports replaced the universal joint with an elastomer or even a metal spring.
summary: Quality of some parts fairly low but this is a great value for a new cargo trailer.

I would give Moultrie 990i an extra star and probably keep buying them rather than Cuddeback. First off, let me adress a few complaints people have made about this blade. Like ALL molle backed gear, the attached straps on the back arrive underneath the horizontal straps. If u unsnap the straps and pull them out, then resnap them OVER TOP of the small horizontal straps, it will accomodate ANY belt, as long as its about 3.5 in wide or less. Thickness is not an issue.
  Which brings me to the next point......the pull the dot snaps, litterally are just that. They are designed so as to never accidentally open, and if u pull the strap at the TOP where the dot is, they unbutton. Then do the opposite when snapping back together, push them on from the bottom side. I found it a little confusing at first, but after getting the hang of it its no prob....
  I own this model and the other original model by rowan (the same co. That makes esee knives), and tho i am typically a fan of rowan stuff over ontario, i do like the ontario model a little bit more....im not going to be some fanboy blabbering about magical heat treats and what not (i love esee knives but some people take it WAY too far).....this ontario model has thicker handle scales. It feels better in the hand.
  For the guy complaining about fading skulls, that will happen naturally with use regardless, there is nothing that you can do. Laser engraving will wear away on micarta, its the nature of the beast. As a side note, you can soak micarta scales in clothing die and they will take the color. Of course u have to go darker and will lose the skulls that would get lost anyways with actual use....
  This may sound bad but i believe it to be true......if u don't know how to sharpen a knife, you have no place spending good money on it. There are a multitude of sharpening systems out there for relatively cheap, get one that works for u before buying knives. I prefer good old fashioned stones (freehand), and finish with a diamond coated rod, and strop....thats just me. I end up sharpening almost ALL my new knives, no matter how sharp.....its rarely sharp enough for my liking straight out of box.....
  I just love the design of this knife. It just plain feels right in my hand. The thumb jimping gives you hell of a lot of leverage, and this knife is a little beast. The only one area that it won't cover is chopping, which is fine with me, tools for the job. I carry hatchets or machetes for that stuff.
  So there you have it....this knife kicks ass! I plan on getting another at some point before the okc models run out.....cuz when they are gone thats it for the made in usa 1095 steel models. All the newer ones are made in italy and are incredibly hard (like 60-61 rockwell).....which im not a fan of....1095 steel rocks!
summary: prefer this model over rowan version

This is my second Invicta watch review. I was quite happy with my first watch, but less so with this one - kinda. I'll explain in a moment.

Looks-wise it's great. Beautiful orange face, nice hands, nice bracelet (no, the rubber one is NOT included, as others have said). The bracelet does come HUGE, but despite what I've read in another review, you don't need a dedicated sizing kit to resolve that  - you need a thing metal pin to push the pin out though. It's not particularly easy, but not hard - I can't remember what I used, but it wasn't a big issues. However, how to size it isn't explained anywhere in the manual, which is a generic book covering many of their watches. Kind of bogus, frankly.

Once sized properly, the bracelet fits and feels fine. No hairs are getting pulled on my wrist, which is nice - that happens sometimes with metal bracelets. It thus far has been fairly accurate as well, so that's a plus. I also like the little magnifying section over the date area. The face is smaller than I thought it would be though; closer to a woman's diving watch size then a man's. Had I seen it and tried it on in person, I think I would have passed, and looked for a slightly larger one - that's personal taste though, and I can see some people perfectly happy with it (I still do wear it - it's not THAT small).

However, as with my other Invicta watch, there is a bit of play in the movement. The second hand doesn't come close to hitting the hash marks on the face, and when you set the time (while I'm on setting, it's one click for date, two for time, and no screw-down crown as you might expect in a diving watch, thogh perhaps not one this cheap), you can turn the crown a bit in each direction without moving the minute hand, making it tough to set it perfectly and make sure it will hit the hash marks after a full minute.

The big negative for me isn't functional, but may point to a lack of care in construction. The bezel (which is actually pretty tough to turn, which is a good thing) doesn't lie consistently around the edge of the crystal. If I run my finger across the face, it's flush on one side, and actually raised up above the crystal on the other. I believe this is just the thin metal ring with the numbers on it (I don't believe there's a leak or anything - been swimming and showering without issue), but I still feel like it shouldn't catch my finger with a sharp metal edge when I touch it.  It wouldn't cut me, but it is, to me, a sign of slightly low quality control and I wonder if that will carry through the rest of the watch.

Thus far though, it hasn't. The crystal seems tough (I've banged it into a few things with no scratches) the time is accurate enough, and it's very comfortable. If you like the looks and don't care about things like a screw-in crown or the absolute highest level of fit and finish, it's an ok value for under a c-note (let's say more than a buck under, though). If, like me, you get obsessive over things like the bezel issue I mentioned, you might want to look elsewhere.
It is really good for treadmills.  I just wish they had a spray hose so that it could spray to the center of the underside of the treadmill belt.

I ordered this paddle because I'm 6'2" and I needed a longer paddle since I ride so high up on my kayak. Upon inspection, it seems to be a fairly well build paddle considering the price. The only reason I give it 4 stars instead of 5 is that the connection point in the center (this is a two piece paddle by the way) seems to be just a little bit loose. I put a little bit of teflon tape on it, and it is snug now, so no problem. I have not taken it out into the waves yet, but I expect it will last. I'll update this after I take it out a few times.

Product Update: So, I've taken it out in green flag and yellow flag (which I probably shouldn't have) surf conditions. Keep in mind, this thing is long, so it gets tiring to use it for long periods of time. HOWEVER, I am growing to like the length, especially in rough surf. The length allows me to get that blade down into the surf to make last second course corrections to avoid flipping. I'm glad I got the long one. If you are going to paddle in light surf or bay/lake conditions, get a shorter paddle. You will kill yourself with this thing.

Product Update #2: It's been quite a while now since I bought the first one. It got older after a LOT of use and I can't get the joint apart anymore. However, I just bought another one. You simply can't beat the price. It is light enough to use for a while without getting tired (I repeat though, if you are going in very calm conditions frequently get a shorter paddle). Joint on the new one is a little loose just like the first, but the first one never gave me any problems, and I used it to get out in 5-6 foot swells (not my wisest idea)...

reviewText:
Okay this isn't a true back packing tent. I say that because it isn't tiny and it weighs a bit more than nothing.

When this tent arrived I pulled it out of the packaging and set it up. It looked nice. I then sprayed the outer shell with "Scotch Guard". I sprayed it enough that it was soaked. I did this three times before letting it sit and dry.

The next time I set this tent up it was on a camping trip. It was 50F and raining lightly as I set up the tent. When we crawled into the tent two hours later it was pouring rain. We were able to leave our boots outside the tent as we snuggled down into our sleeping bags for the night.

Outside it was pouring and the wind was blowing. It was chilly at about 40F. (Hey this is south Florida.) Inside the tent we were dry and with the ventilation we stayed dry all night.

This tent may not be the lightest tent I have worked with but it does have the possibility of being the most versatile for dealing with the weather and heat of south Florida.

In other words it's well worth the price.

Although I didn't buy this one from amazon, I bought the exact same one from Dick's sporting goods on a black Friday special for about $130.  It was a Christmas present to myself so that I could get back into archery hunting.  (PA allows crossbows for archery)  I followed the directions for assembly with no problems.

Its fairly easy to cock with the string/assist pulley like device.  The trigger isn't great, but its not too bad either.

I can hit very accurately out to 40 yards.  I use the various marks on the scope for different ranges.  I even printed a diagram of the scope reticle and wrote which mark was for which distance.  I taped that to the stock so that I would never forget where to shoot at a particular distance target.

I chronographed the bolts with 100 grain tips at about 200 fps.  It's not the advertised 235fps, but still not too bad.  If you use that speed and weight bolt, you get an energy that is good enough for deer hunting.

I took it for archery season last year and got a doe on the last day of the season from my treestand.  I was about a 30 yard shot, went through both sides of the deer.  I found her about 40 yards from where I shot her.

Small drawbacks:  the scope is not the best quality.  It does work OK, but there is some distortion at the edge of the field.  My first string frayed and began to unwind after only a few shots.  I emailed the manufacturer and they sent me 2 free replacement strings in the mail.  The bolts are crap, throw them away and use better ones.  Even with there cons, I think its a great deal.  I thought about buying a more expensive one, but this one works fine, I might just use it indefinitely.

reviewText:
I actually purchased this Gerber Bear Fixed Blade to replace a Smith & Wesson fixed blade I loved, but was just too big to comfortably carry, especially as an EDC. When I received this knife in very short order, I thought this might have been a mistake. I mean really, how can one take a knife with bright orange markings seriously, right? Other than being the trade mark of this Gerber brand that turns out to be no challenge at all. This fixed blade knife is about 7 3/4 inches overall length, with a 3 1/2 inch blade. In my state, nice and legal as an EDC, even if concealed I would not expect any hassle due to its size. It arrived very quickly, in excellent condition, well packaged and the knife is sheathed in a molded, heavy-duty, formed  plastic with the Gerber logo. The knife easily slides and clicks into a secure, yet easily removable position in the sheath. No special tricks are needed to remove the knife, but it remains securely in place and may be worn in or outside the waistband or boot. I was surprised at how sharp the blade was upon receipt, but still added a surgical edge myself. I like the drop point blades versus the tanto tip as a personal preference. The blade edge is a functional combination of straight edge and serrated for multiple uses. The first time I wore the knife on my waistband I was pleasantly surprised at how comfortably it 'snuggled' into my side and just a little higher than my other EDC knives.

This is a great little fixed blade knife for a multiple use tool or convenient EDC. I don't think I would be whacking on tree limbs and things with it, but then again, that is not the purpose or reason I purchased it. I would give this knife a very high recommendation for all the reasons listed above and because of the confidence it can do the job.
summary: Don't Let It's Appearance Fool You

I am 5'11, 206 pounds.  I got the 3XL size because I did NOT want it to be tight at all.  I can't stand jackets that are tight or "ride up" on you in the sleeves or at the waist.

This jacket fits nicely, probably slightly too big, but I'd rather that than the opposite.

That being said, It works, it's good, it's comfortable, but the wrists are not tight around my hands and a lot of cold air was blowing into the jacket.  Not the jackets fault because i got a big size, but be warned that you may have air travel into the jacket.

I also wore a thick tshirt underneath.  I actually sweat in the jacket, then the cold hit at night and that made me REALLY cold.  That may be a problem with a warm jacket, you do not want to sweat.

Think about your options, but I really like this jacket, I'm glad it's not tight, I would order it again and probably get the same 3XL size.

reviewText: I have had an Old Hickory knife in my camping set of utensils for many years and I have loved that knife and the way it holds an edge so much that I bought an entire set of Old Hickory. I was not at all happy with what I received. The slicing knife has a large corrosive spot on the blade and I haven't even taken it out of the package. All of the rest of the knives needed sharpening so badly that I ended up spending an additional $50 to have a pro sharpen them. Even after having these new knives sharpened, the blade was not the same feel as my old Old Hickory knife. I ended up purchasing a J.A. Henckels International Forged Premio and have been very happy with the quality. I wish that I would have gotten the Premio set in the first place.
summary: Not the quality of knives that I expected

I received this brush kit for free to test and review. I tried it out and it works.

I noted that one person said the brush broke off inside their tubing. Due to that review, I did everything I could to force the brush to break off in my hand before I ran it through my tubing!!! I did not want a repeat of that performance. Thankfully, all three of the brushes sent to me remain firmly attached to their handles as did the bristles. I also noted the strength of the long cable attached to the tubing brush, again, I did not want to destroy my tubing due to a faulty brush.

This set is a universal set but it won't clean all packs equally well. I found this to be around 3 inches too short to fully clean my tubing. When I clean tubing, I want the bristles to exit the other side, not be a few inches from the end. This is my fault, I should have measured before accepting the review request. I did not feel as if the brushes ends were going to break off, but I tested before use. I found no problems with damage to the brush, the cables, handles or most importantly, to my tubing!

The other two brushes work very well. I was able to clean out my bite tube, and the hanger is the greatest for helping my pack dry. (Better than my routine of hang it upside down on a wooden spoon.

All in all, this is a good kit, just be sure to measure your tubing so you aren't leaving bacteria in part of your tube. It's like the one size fits all clothing, there are some sizes it fits better.

I just installed this bracket on my concrete garage wall. This unit is quite heavy, and provides for infinite adjustment which was my major reason for purchase versus the alternatives. As noted in prior reviews, the installation instruction are sparse regarding wall mounting, and the correct height to mount on a wall. Here are some of my installation suggestions and hints. First, I suggest that you test assemble it loosely with all of the components that you will be using for your installation on a workbench, so that you can see everything working together before you mount it (there will be parts left over). From that test assembly, I determined the amount of travel (elevation adjustment) available in the screw jack. If you mount the the bottom of the base plate on the wall at 8' above the driveway the rim height can be adjusted from about 7' to just over 10' at the top of the screw's travel. (The instructions give a minimum elevation reference from a hole in the middle of the mount to the ground, which is an odd way to provide this measurement.) I mounted the base plate into the solid concrete beam over the garage door, with 4" lag screws into long lag screw expanding sheilds. My only complaint about the screw jack mechanism is that is seemed to be inadequately lubricated from the factory. I took mine apart (remove the hook from the bottom) and discovered that it had only a small smear of grease on the middle of the screw. I completely greased the screw, the bearing washers and the sliding surfaces of the tubes with white lithium grease. This makes the action smoother, and will hopefully prevent corrosion. Lastly, when doing the final mounting, do not tighten all of the fasteners completely in each step of assembly. Having some "play" in the joints makes getting all of the bolt holes to line up easier. I did this entire installation alone (not recommended) and offer this last tip for the most awkward part of the assembly, mounting the backboard to the elevator arms. I held the backboard upside-down and backwards to then insert the bottom bolt through the bottom elevator arms and through the bottom backboard mounting holes. The bottom arms are hanging low to the ground at this point, so you're lower on the ladder, and more stable in this position. Then using the bottom bolt as a pivot point, swing the backboard upward into its final position (with the upper arms cranked down to the lowest position to make it easier to reach) and insert the upper bolt through the upper arms and upper backboard mounting holes. I did mounted the backboard without the rim in place to make it less cumbersome and lighter. When the mount and the backboard are all loosely assembled, then go back and tighten all of the fasteners to their final tightness.
summary: Excellent adjustment features - Review with installation notes

If you're into bushcraft, or survivalism,  this is the knife to carry.  This knife is 1 pound of solid steel. The spine of the knife is the thickest I've ever seen on any knife out there.  This knife can easily baton through 4" pieces of wood.  The scales are synthetic and have a great feel to them.  The edge is quite sharp, but you're not going to shave with it, but no knife this big can do that.  If you want a razor, buy a Cold Steel Recon 1.  This knife is for heavy work in the field.  Another good feature, it's made in the USA.  The only foreign part is the sheath, which is made in Taiwan, but it's actually built very well. The knife locks into the sheath very tight. It will take some breaking in to loosen it up. You don't have to worry about it falling out or losing it. There is a lanyard hole at the end of the knife, as well as holes in the knife sheath if you want to lace in some paracord.

Ka-Bar made this knife like a tank. It's just a tough, rugged piece of equipment. If I had to go into the field with the choice of only one knife, this one would surely be my top vote.  I've seen this knife priced much higher than what is advertised here.  So you're not only getting a quality tool, you're not being taken to the cleaners buying it either.  It's a heckuva deal.

I've been a survivalist for over 25 years, and I would trust my life to this knife.
summary: One of the best bushcraft knives made!

I wear size 10 US (43 Euro) Pearl iZumi Vagabond R3 road cycling shoe & ordered the L/XL Thermal Toe Covers. I've ridden in cool/windy conditions & these Covers are a noticeable improvement. These Covers reach just over the middle strap of my shoes & the L/XL fit is appropriate. Snug enough that the Cover molds to the shoe & doesn't move but with enough slack that I can easily roll the top part of the Cover down to expose the shoe's middle strap. This is a key part of the fit I hadn't considered - I can slide shoes on/off just by loosening the top 2 straps which has allowed me to keep the Covers on all Winter as opposed to pulling on/off every time I ride. Nice time-saver.

Overall outstanding value for $ & easy to use with PI road shoes.
summary: Excellent value for added protection from wind chill

I have grown up in the fighting industry and have trained with many ropes, this is my second crossfit style wire rope. Some reviews have said the set up was hard since the product comes with no instructions.  Here is how you would do it, unravel the wire rope and align one of the ends at the opening of your armpit, step with both feet onto the wire rope and pull the other end up to your armpit. At this length you will cut the rope with wire cutters and feed the wire rope through the handle ball then slide on the silver screw stop and place the black cap on the ends of the rope for protection from the wire, now tighten down the silver screw stop with a screw driver. You are ready to start jumping.

The swing of the rope is really smooth and I am currently working on getting double unders. This is a great speed rope for crossfit, boxing, MMA, and kind of cardio endurance workout. However I would not recommend using this on rough concrete or asphalt, the coating around the wire will easily wear through. I hope this review was helpful to you!

reviewText:
I must admit I wasn't expecting too much from this Viking Nature Solar Camping Shower Bag but shortly prove me wrong. We have used it already on two camping trips and we used it daily and I absolutely love it. My solar camp shower worked as advertised. Heating water takes some time, but goes much faster if you put the bag on the roof or hood of your car. Going without showers during camping can be a little bit stinky, but now there is no excuse. Getting a shower is super refreshing...it is great to get the sweat and smoke smell off of your body. For this price you cant really go wrong. It packs up small and 5 gallons is plenty of water for two-three people if you know how to conserve water.

We fill it with water and lay it in the sun for 2-3 hours, hoist it up on a post in the shower, and the two of us can shower with more than enough hot water. To be sure, we both have very short hair; some with lots of hair may run short to get a complete rinse.
I really recommend it to anyone who loves camping and cant go out too long without showering, it does get the job done. Please note: Seller has provided me with a discount to try and test Viking Nature Solar Camping Shower Bag and this is my truly, unbiased and honest comment about this product after testing for over several camping trips.
summary: Best thing to have in all your camping trips

reviewText: So this case will hold six or seven pistols no problem.  It's lightweight and robust enough for trips to the range where the only action it will see is the trunk to the shooting bench.  The reason for three stars is the padding.  There isn't enough of it, or I should say it isn't thick enough.  With only the top level filled with guns the padding isn't thick enough to hold the guns securely.  My guns bang into one another... not good.  I was able to solve the problem by putting a bunch of folded paper towels on the bottom below the bottom pad.  I shouldn't have to do that; but what do you expect for a $20 product.  After my admittedly ghetto solution the product works great.  I cannot see the paper towels so out of sight out of mind I guess.  Just wish that the padding was more robust to begin with.
Works good with my Ruger LCR.
summary: Works good with my Ruger LCR

reviewText:
I have owned this multi tool for years. And while I love it, I can not say that I'm IN love with it. The pros for this tool are the Allen assembly that allows you to swap out tools, and completely disassemble the tool for cleaning. The plier heads can be angled to get into tight spaces. The overall design is ultra sleek, and lightweight.

The cons I found with this multi tool were odd, didn't affect it's daily use, and with care (and in my case brains :P) could easily be overcome. The tools don't actually 'lock' into place, when they fold out they seem to be held just by compression. This is fine for most uses but just be careful not to go trying to break a stubborn bolt loose, or you will ruin your knuckles. When using the pliers, think carefully about where you want your hands to go when the head folds up or down unexpectedly. I have used the angle headed feature maybe a handful of times, always just to grab something that fell, never to try and loosen something with it. I was slightly disappointed with the number of tools available from SOG to swap out. Sure a seatbelt cutter is awesome, but I feel that they really could use this design as a skunk works to test new concepts in what a multi tool could be. swap out all 5 tools on one side for a spring loaded window punch? Why not? Instead of pliers, have a RG45 crimper? Crazier things have been tried, and who knows maybe it changes the world of multi tool forever.

All in all, I would recommend the Paratool for anyone who needs a smaller, lightweight tool for tightening the occasional screw. And cracking the occasional beer. For something that is a little easier to open one handed, check out a gerber. But for a utilitarian tough as nails multi tool that you can break down to your zany little fixer hearts content, look no further.
summary: It's not you baby, it's me!

reviewText: Dry freezes food to take on camping trips. Just add hotwater, stir and let sit. Ready to eat in about 8-10 minutes. Decent flavor for being freeze dried then brought back to life. Easy to make and carry. Two portion bag. Liked the flavor not bad at all. Will try other flavored.

reviewText: I am comparing this to Smith & Wesson Pepper Shield Quick Release Pepper Spray Keychain with Clear Key Cap, .50-Ounce, Black Finish, which I have had in my survival fanny pack for a while. Product -- Sabre Spitfire Volume -- .21 OZ Active ingredient -- oleoresin capsicum of unknown strength Range -- 8 feet Is it cute? -- Yes Cost? -- currently more expensive Product -- Smith & Wesson Pepper Shield Volume -- .5 Oz Active ingredient -- 15% oleoresin capsicum (maximum strength) Range -- 10 feet Is it cute? -- No Cost? -- currently less expensive Obviously the plain grey canister from Smith and Wesson is a better deal. So there isn't much to recommend this product, unless cuteness is important to you. Also, I am kind of annoyed about the pink ribbon and the "National Breast Cancer Foundation Inc." logo. I thought pink ribbons were associated with the Susan G Komen Foundation and this product apparently has nothing to do with breast cancer. There is no mention of a donation, and the other color canisters don't have pink ribbons. So why is it there? Is the Sabre company using a charity logo to sell a product? I hope not, because that would be profiting from the suffering of sick women.
